{{Infobox ice hockey team season |League=NHL |Season=2001–02 |year=2001 |Team=Calgary Flames |Conference=[[Western Conference (NHL)|Western]] |ConferenceRank=11th |Division=[[Northwest Division (NHL)|Northwest]] |DivisionRank=4th |Record=32–35–12–3 |HomeRecord=20–14–5–2 |RoadRecord=12–21–7–1 |GoalsFor=201 (22nd) |GoalsAgainst=220 (20th) |GeneralManager=[[Craig Button]] |Coach=[[Greg Gilbert]] |Captain=[[Dave Lowry]] (Oct-Feb)
[[Bob Boughner]] (Feb-Apr)
[[Craig Conroy]] (Feb-Apr) |AltCaptain=[[Jarome Iginla]]
[[Robyn Regehr]] |Arena=[[Pengrowth Saddledome]] |Attendance=15,705 |GoalsLeader=[[Jarome Iginla]] (52) |AssistsLeader=[[Craig Conroy]] (48) |PointsLeader=Jarome Iginla (96) |PIMLeader=[[Bob Boughner]] (170) |WinsLeader=[[Roman Turek]] (30) |GAALeader=Roman Turek (2.53) }} The '''[[2001–02 NHL season|2001–02]] [[Calgary Flames]] season''' was the [[Calgary Flames seasons|22nd]] [[National Hockey League]] [[season (sports)|season]] in Calgary. It began with wholesale changes, as second year General Manager [[Craig Button]] continued to change the look of the team. In two separate draft-day trades, the Flames dealt goaltender [[Fred Braithwaite]] and forwards [[Valeri Bure]] and [[Jason Wiemer]] away, gaining back [[Roman Turek]] and [[Rob Niedermayer]]. The changes appeared to pay off, as the Flames stormed out to a 13–2–2–2 record, and first place in the division. The result prompted the Flames to sign Turek - a pending unrestricted free agent - to a long-term deal.[http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2001/11/19/turek011119.html Flames ink Turek long-term], cbc sports, November 20, 2001, accessed December 19, 2006. The team, however, collapsed, winning only 19 of their remaining 63 games, finishing 4th in the [[Northwest Division (NHL)|Northwest Division]], and out of the playoffs for the sixth consecutive season. The season ended with head coach [[Greg Gilbert]] and top forward [[Marc Savard]] in a bitter, public feud that included the latter demanding a trade late in the season and into the summer.[http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2002/11/15/flames021115.html Flames ship Savard to Thrashers], cbc sports, November 15, 2002, accessed December 19, 2006. Individually, [[Jarome Iginla]] broke into the spotlight, leading the NHL in goals (52) and points (96). His season would land him the [[Rocket Richard Trophy]], the [[Art Ross Trophy]] and the [[Lester B. Pearson Award]].[http://proicehockey.about.com/library/bltrophywin2002.htm NHL Awards 2002], proicehockey.about.com, accessed December 19, 2006. Iginla also finished second in [[Hart Memorial Trophy]] voting, tied with winner [[José Théodore|Jose Theodore]] on points (434), but behind Theodore in first place votes (26–23).[http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2002/06/20/nhlawards020620.html Jose Theodore named NHL MVP], cbc sports, June 27, 2002, accessed December 19, 2006. Iginla was also a member of [[Canada men's national ice hockey team|Canada's]] team at the [[Ice hockey at the 2002 Winter Olympics|2002 Salt Lake Olympics]]. He recorded two goals in the gold medal game against the [[United States men's national ice hockey team|United States]], which Canada won 5–2 to claim their first ice hockey gold medal in 50 years.[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/olympics/2002/ice_hockey/news/2002/02/24/usa_canada_ap/ Stand on guard for thee], CNNSI.com, February 24, 2002, accessed December 22, 2006. {{TOClimit|limit=2}} ==Regular season== The Flames were involved in a tragic incident during their March 16, 2002, game in Columbus against the [[Columbus Blue Jackets|Blue Jackets]]. During the second period of the contest, a slapshot by Columbus' [[Espen Knutsen]] was deflected into the crowd off the stick of Flames defenceman [[Derek Morris (ice hockey)|Derek Morris]]. The puck struck a fan, 13-year-old Brittanie Cecil, who was at her first NHL game. Though she was able to leave the game under her own power, the blow tore a vertebral artery and resulted in a blood clot. [[Death of Brittanie Cecil|She died]] two days later; she was the first fan to die at a game in the NHL's 85-year history.{{cite news |last=MacFarlane |first=Steve |url=http://www.calgarysun.com/2012/03/14/10-years-after-the-death-of-brittanie-cecil |title=Death of Brittanie: Cecil 10 years later |work=Calgary Sun |date=2012-03-15 |accessdate=2012-03-15 |page=22}} Three months after the incident, the NHL instituted a policy requiring that protective netting be placed around the ends of each rink prior to the start of the [[2002–03 NHL season|2002–03 season]], a decision which both the Flames and Blue Jackets advocated.{{cite news |last=MacFarlane |first=Steve |title=Net reaction |work=Calgary Sun |date=2012-03-15 |page=23}} {{2001–02 NHL The Flames had the 11th overall pick, however traded it to the [[Phoenix Coyotes]] in a swap that saw them gain the 14th pick. {| class="wikitable" width="75%" |- !rowspan="2"|Rnd !rowspan="2"|Pick !rowspan="2"|Player !rowspan="2"|Nationality !rowspan="2"|Position !rowspan="2"|Team (league) !colspan="5"|NHL statistics |- !GP!!G!!A!!Pts!!PIM |- |1||14||[[Chuck Kobasew]]||{{CAN}}||[[Winger (sports)|RW]]||[[Boston College]] ([[Hockey East|HE]])||601||110||100||210||394 |- |2||41||[[Andrei Taratukhin]]||{{RUS}}||[[Centre (ice hockey)|C]]||[[Avangard Omsk]] ([[Russian Super League|RSL]])|| || || || || |- |2||56||[[Andrei Medvedev (ice hockey)|Andrei Medvedev]]||{{RUS}}||[[Goaltender|G]]||[[HC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moscow]] (RSL)|| || || || || |- |4||108||[[Tomi Mäki|Tomi Maki]]||{{FIN}}||RW||[[Jokerit]] ([[SM-liiga|FIN]])||1||0||0||0||0 |- |4||124||[[Egor Shastin]]||{{RUS}}||[[Forward (ice hockey)|F]]||Avangard Omsk (RSL)|| || || || || |- |5||145||James Hakewill||{{USA}}||[[Defenceman|D]]||Westminster (USHS)|| || || || || |- |5||164||[[Yuri Trubachev]]||{{RUS}}||C||St. Petersburg (RUS)|| || || || || |- |7||207||[[Garrett Bembridge]]||{{CAN}}||RW||[[Saskatoon Blades]] ([[Western Hockey League|WHL]])|| || || || || |- |7||220||[[David Moss (ice hockey)|David Moss]]†||{{USA}}||RW||[[Cedar Rapids RoughRiders]] ([[United States Hockey League|USHL]])||501||78||100||178||157 |- |8||233||Joe Campbell||{{USA}}||D||[[Des Moines Buccaneers]] (USHL)|| || || || |- |8||251||[[Ville Hamalainen]]||{{FIN}}||RW||[[SaiPa]] (FIN)|| || || || || |} :Statistics are updated to the end of the [[2014–15 NHL season]]. † denotes player was on an NHL roster in 2014–15. ==Farm teams== ===[[Saint John Flames]]=== The baby Flames followed up their [[Calder Cup]] winning season with a disappointing 29–34–13–4 result in [[2001–02 AHL season|2001–02]], finishing in last place in the Canadian Division, missing the playoffs. [[Blair Betts]] led the Flames with just 49 points, while [[Dany Sabourin]] was the top goaltender in limited action.[http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/leagues/seasons/teams/0002602002.html 2001–02 Saint John Flames stats], hockeydb.com, accessed December 21, 2006. ===[[Johnstown Chiefs]]=== The Chiefs finished the [[2001–02 ECHL season|2001–02]] [[ECHL]] season with a 39–31–2 record, good enough for third place in the Northwest Division. They were knocked out of the playoffs in the second round by the [[Dayton Bombers]]. == See also == * [[2001–02 NHL season]] == References == {{refbegin}} * '''Player stats:''' 2006–07 Calgary Flames Media Guide - 2001–02 stats, p. 110. * '''Game log:''' [http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/teams/schedule?team=cgy&season=2002 2001–02 Calgary Flames game log] on espn.com. * '''Team standings:''' [http://www.hockeydb.com/ihdb/stats/leagues/seasons/nhl19272002.html 2001–02 NHL standings] at hockeydb.com. {{refend}} {{reflist}} {{Calgary Flames seasons}} {{Calgary Flames}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2001-02 Calgary Flames Season}} [[Category:Calgary Flames seasons]] [[Category:2001–02 NHL season by team|Calgary Flames season, 2001-02]] [[Category:2001–02 in Canadian ice hockey by team|Cal]]

{{Cleanup|date=August 2015|reason=article is without citation, and is missing information)}} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Abu Dhabi International Tennis Centre | nickname = | image = | location = [[Zayed Sports City]] [[Abu Dhabi]], [[UAE]] | built = ? | opened = 2004 | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Capitala World Tennis Championship]] | seating_capacity = 5,000 (centre court)
600 (court 2) }} The '''International Tennis Centre''', also known as '''Abu Dhabi International Tennis Complex''', is a sports [[arena]] in [[Abu Dhabi]], [[United Arab Emirates]]. The complex opened in 2004 as part of the [[Zayed Sports City]]. It has a [[seating capacity]] of 5,000 on Centre Court and 600 on Court 2. The sports city features three other major sporting and leisure facilities. ==Construction== The idea for a sporting complex in Abu Dhabi was brought up by Sheikh [[Zayed Bin Sultan Al Nahyan]], the late former UAE president and Sheikh [[Khalifa Bin Zayed Al Nahyan]], the incumbent president. Abu Dhabi Municipalities and Town Planning Department were given the task of building a Tennis Complex to rival all other venues. ==Tournaments== The first tournament held at the venue was the ''Abu Dhabi Professional Tennis Tournament2006'' which was part of the ATP futures series in 2006. In 2009 a professional exhibition event, the [[Capitala World Tennis Championship]] was held for the first time, with six of the world's top ten players in attendance. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.mubadalawtc.com/ Official site] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081224032053/http://www.capitalawtc.com/en/Venue.aspx Capitala World Tennis Championship site] *[http://wikimapia.org/#lat=24.4135469&lon=54.4592124&z=18&l=0&m=a&v=2 map Wikimapia Official site] {{coord|24.4138204|54.4593036|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 2004]] [[Category:Tennis venues in the United Arab Emirates]] [[Category:Sports venues in Abu Dhabi]] [[Category:2004 establishments in the United Arab Emirates]] {{UnitedArabEmirates-sports-venue-stub}}

{{use mdy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Albert–Daly Field | nickname = Martin Family Stadium | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Albert-daly.jpg | caption = August 2011 | fullname = Martin Family Stadium at Albert–Daly Field | former_names = | location = [[Williamsburg, Virginia]] | coordinates = {{coord|37.2911599|-76.7329574|type:landmark_region:US-VA|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = {{start date|2004|08|28}} | renovated = | expanded = 2010 | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = [[College of William & Mary]] | surface = Natural grass | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 1,000 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[William & Mary Tribe men's soccer]]
[[William & Mary Tribe women's soccer]] }} '''Albert–Daly Field''' is a [[Soccer-specific stadium|soccer-specific]] and multi-use sports facility located in [[Williamsburg, Virginia]] on the campus of the [[College of William and Mary]]. It is home to the [[soccer]] and [[lacrosse]] teams for the College. The facility was paid for thanks in large part to a sizable challenge grant made by Jim and Bobbie Ukrop. The Ukrops suggested that the field be named in honor of long time soccer coaches [[Al Albert (soccer coach)|Al Albert]] and [[John Daly (soccer coach)|John Daly]]. Opened in 2004, the original venue consisted of a natural grass playing surface, lighting, and temporary bleacher seating.{{cite web|title=Martin Family Stadium at Albert-Daly Field|url=http://www.tribeathletics.com/story.php/1345|website=tribeathletics.com|accessdate=June 15, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101128202239/http://tribeathletics.com/story.php/1345|archivedate=November 28, 2010|year=2010}} In 2010, the College broke ground on a new 1,000-seat spectator pavilion at Albert–Daly Field. The structure, '''Martin Family Stadium''', is named in honor of Eff and Patty Martin, and their children. In addition to spectator seating, the building boasts a state-of-the-art press box, filming positions, and restroom facilities. The project was completed in the spring of 2011.{{cite web|title=Martin Family Stadium at Albert-Daly Field|url=http://www.tribeathletics.com/news/2011/1/7/205073195.aspx|publisher=College of William and Mary|accessdate=27 May 2016}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{William & Mary Tribe women's soccer}} {{The College of William & Mary}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Albert-Daly Field}} [[Category:2004 establishments in Virginia]] [[Category:College soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Virginia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2004]] [[Category:Sports venues in Hampton Roads]] [[Category:William & Mary Tribe soccer]] [[Category:William & Mary Tribe sports venues]] [[Category:Defunct National Premier Soccer League stadiums]] {{Virginia-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.comment: /* History of use in Major League Baseball */
revision.text:
In [[baseball]], a '''corked bat''' is a specially modified [[baseball bat]] that has been filled with [[cork (material)|cork]] or other lighter, less dense substances to make the bat lighter. A lighter bat gives a hitter a quicker swing and may improve the hitter's timing. In [[Major League Baseball]], modifying a bat with foreign substances and using it in play is illegal and subject to ejection and further punishment. ==Construction of corked bats== To cork a bat, a hole approximately 1/2-inch (12.5 mm) in diameter is drilled down through the thick end of the bat roughly six inches deep. Crushed cork, [[bouncy ball]], sawdust, or other similar material is compacted into the hole and the end is typically patched up with glue and sawdust. However, this weakens the bat's structural integrity and makes it more susceptible to breakage, even more so if the cork is placed beyond roughly six inches into the bat. Corked bats are typically discovered when they break during play. Corked bats were tested in the [[MythBusters (2007 season)#Episode 83 – "Baseball Myths"|2007 season of MythBusters]] where it was found that the cork was detrimental to the bat's performance. ==Corked bats in Major League Baseball== Using a corked bat in Major League Baseball is in violation of Rule 6.06 (d), which reads in full:"[http://mlb.mlb.com/NASApp/mlb/mlb/official_info/official_rules/batter_6.jsp MLB Official Rules, Section 6]", ''MLB.com'' (accessed June 8, 2006)
A batter is out for illegal action when: (d) He uses or attempts to use a bat that, in the umpire's judgment, has been altered or tampered with in such a way to improve the distance factor or cause an unusual reaction on the baseball. This includes, bats that are filled, flat surfaced, nailed, hollowed, grooved or covered with a substance such as paraffin, wax, etc. No advancement on the bases will be allowed and any out or outs made during a play shall stand. In addition to being called out, the player shall be ejected from the game and may be subject to additional penalties as determined by his League Punishment advisor.
While filling a bat with cork makes it lighter, there is no rule that prevents a player from using a lighter, uncorked bat.{{cite episode|title=MythBusters Baseball Special|episodelink=MythBusters (2007 season)#Episode 83 – Baseball Myths|series=MythBusters|serieslink=MythBusters|airdate=2007-08-08|season=6|number=83}} However, lighter wood bats are shorter than heavier bats.{{cite web|url=http://www.smithsonianmag.com/science-nature/The-Physics-of-Cheating-in-Baseball.html |title=History, Travel, Arts, Science, People, Places | Smithsonian |publisher=Smithsonianmag.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-10}} ===History of use in Major League Baseball=== Since {{by|1970}}, six players have been caught using corked bats. The following table summarizes these events: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Player ! Team ! Date ! Suspension ! Offense ! Excuse |- | [[Sammy Sosa]] | [[Chicago Cubs]] | June 3, 2003 | Eight games"[http://static.espn.go.com/mlb/news/2003/0611/1566433.html Corked bat-related penalty reduced by one game]", ''ESPN.com news services'', June 11, 2003 (accessed March 6, 2009) | Corked bat | Bat was meant to only be used in [[batting practice]] |- | [[Wilton Guerrero]] | [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] | June 1, 1997 | Eight games | Corked bat | None |- | [[Chris Sabo]] | [[Cincinnati Reds]] | July 29, 1996 | Seven games; Reds fined $25,000 | Corked bat"[http://chicago.cubs.mlb.com/NASApp/mlb/mlb/news/mlb_news.jsp?ymd=20030606&content_id=358688&vkey=news_mlb&fext=.jsp Sosa gets eight games, appeals] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041018152633/http://chicago.cubs.mlb.com/NASApp/mlb/mlb/news/mlb_news.jsp?ymd=20030606&content_id=358688&vkey=news_mlb&fext=.jsp |date=2004-10-18 }}", ''MLB.com'' (accessed June 28, 2006) | Borrowed bat from unnamed teammate |- | [[Albert Belle]] | [[Cleveland Indians]] | [[1994 Cleveland Indians corked bat incident|July 15, 1994]] | Seven games | Corked bat | None |- | [[Billy Hatcher]] | [[Houston Astros]] | August 31, 1987 | Ten days | Corked bat | Borrowed bat from pitcher ([[Dave Smith (pitcher, born 1955)|Dave Smith]]) |- | [[Graig Nettles]] | [[New York Yankees]] | September 7, 1974 | Ten days | Six [[Super Ball|super balls]] in bat | Received bat as a gift from a fan |} In addition, former player and Major League manager [[Phil Garner]] admitted in January 2010 on a Houston radio station that he used a corked bat against [[Gaylord Perry]] and "hit a home run" with it.{{cite web|url=http://67.72.16.166/kilt2/2154640.mp3|title=2154640}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 2010, ''[[Deadspin]]'' reported that [[Pete Rose]] used corked bats during his 1985 pursuit of [[Ty Cobb]]'s all-time hits record. Two sports memorabilia collectors who owned Rose's game-used bats from that season had the bats [[x-rayed]] and found the telltale signs of corking.{{cite news|last1=Petchesky|first1=Barry|title=This Is Pete Rose's Corked Bat|url=http://deadspin.com/5555714/this-is-pete-roses-corked-bat|accessdate=16 June 2016|work=[[Deadspin]]|publisher=[[Gawker Media]]|date=June 8, 2010}}{{cite news|last1=Littmann|first1=Chris|title=Corked Bats Reportedly Belonging to Pete Rose Come to Light|url=https://www.sbnation.com/2010/6/8/1647180/corked-bats-reportedly-belonging|accessdate=16 June 2016|work=[[SBNation]]|date=8 June 2010}} Rose had previously denied using corked bats.{{cite news|title=Pete Rose interview|url=http://reds.enquirer.com/2004/01/13/red2qa.html|accessdate=16 June 2016|work=[[Cincinnati Enquirer]]|date=January 13, 2004}} == Notes == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://static.espn.go.com/mlb/s/2003/0603/1562807.html Doctored bat infractions] – ESPN. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090627125841/http://paws.kettering.edu/~drussell/bats-new/corkedbat.html What about corked bats?] [[Category:Baseball terminology]] [[Category:Deception]] [[Category:Banned sports tactics]] [[Category:Baseball bats]]

{{Infobox stadium | name = Doak Field | nickname = The Doak | fullname = Doak Field at Dail Park | image = Doak Field.jpg | image_size = 220 | location = [[Raleigh, North Carolina|Raleigh]], [[North Carolina]] | coordinates = {{coord|35|47|14|N|78|40|46|W|type:landmark|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1966 | closed = | renovated = 2004 | demolished = | owner = [[North Carolina State University]] | operator = North Carolina State University | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | dimensions = Left Field - {{convert|320|ft|m|abbr=on}}
Center Field - {{convert|400|ft|m|abbr=on}}
Right Field - {{convert|330|ft|m|abbr=on}} | tenants = [[North Carolina State University]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA baseball]])
[[Atlantic Coast Conference Baseball Tournament]] (1974, 1980) | seating_capacity = 3,000 (2,500 chairback seats) }} '''Doak Field''' (or '''The Doak''') is a [[baseball]] venue in [[Raleigh, North Carolina]], [[United States]]. It opened in 1966 and is home to the [[North Carolina State University]] [[North Carolina State Wolfpack|Wolfpack]] [[college baseball]] team of the [[NCAA]]'s [[List of NCAA Division I baseball programs|Division I]] [[Atlantic Coast Conference]] (ACC).{{cite web|title=Doak Field at Dail Park|url=http://www.ballparkdigest.com/200903101548/college-baseball/visits/doak-field-at-dail-park-north-carolina-state-wolfpack|work=Ballpark Digest|accessdate=19 August 2011}} It is named for [[Charles Doak]], who was the head coach of the NC State baseball team from 1924–1939.{{cite web |title=2012 NC State Baseball Yearbook |url=http://www.packyearbooks.com/2011-12-baseball-yearbook/files/2.html |work=PackYearbooks.com |publisher=NC State Sports Information |accessdate=2 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68rfHLNqO?url=http://www.packyearbooks.com/2011-12-baseball-yearbook/files/2.html |archivedate=2012-07-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The stadium is located on NC State's [[North Carolina State University Main Campus#Central Campus|West Campus]], behind Lee and Sullivan residence halls.{{cite web|title=Central Campus Precinct Map|url=http://www.ncsu.edu/campus_map/central.htm|work=NCSU|accessdate=19 August 2011}} The diamond is in the north/northwest corner of its block, which is bounded by Thurman Drive (third base, north/northeast); Dail Park and the residence halls (left field, east/southeast); Sullivan Drive (right field, south/southwest); and Varsity Drive (first base, west/northwest). Its seating capacity is 2,500 spectators, with an overflow capacity of 3,000. The largest crowd at Doak Field since its 2004 renovation was 3,109 on April 28, 2007, in a series finale between NC State and its rival UNC.{{Cite web|title = North Carolina Rides Six-Run Eighth Inning To 9-3 Win Over NC State|url = http://www.gopack.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/042807aab.html|accessdate = 2015-06-04}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Doak Field hosted the [[Atlantic Coast Conference Baseball Tournament]] in both [[1974 Atlantic Coast Conference Baseball Tournament|1974]] and in [[Atlantic Coast Conference Baseball Tournament|1980]]. NC State won the championship in 1974, while [[Clemson Tigers baseball|Clemson]] won in 1980.{{cite web |title=Doak Field at Dail Park |url=http://www.gopack.com/facilities/doak-field.html |work=Go Pack |accessdate=19 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68roVh26R?url=http://www.gopack.com/facilities/doak-field.html |archivedate=2012-07-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Prior to 1966, the Wolfpack played their home games at [[Riddick Stadium]], which was primarily a football facility.{{cite web |title=Riddick Stadium |url=http://www.ncsu.edu/facilities/buildings/ridd-sta.html |work=NCSU.edu |accessdate=2 June 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/687vR7K64?url=http://www.ncsu.edu/facilities/buildings/ridd-sta.html |archivedate=2012-06-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }} [[File:Doak Field at Dail Park Press Box.JPG|thumb|Doak Field at Dail Park]] In May 2004, the stadium underwent a [[USD|$]]6 million renovation which included leveling the playing field, a new drainage system, new grandstands, a new [[press box]], and new concessions and bathroom facilities. Since the renovation was completed in 2004, the dimensions at Doak Field are asymmetrical at 320 feet down the left-field line, 370 feet to the left-field power alley, 400 feet to straightaway center field, 375 feet to the right-field power alley, and 330 down the right-field line. The wall from the left-field line to deep left-center field is 16 feet high, then drops to eight feet high all the rest of the way around to right field.{{cite web |title=Doak Field |url=https://projects.ncsu.edu/facilities/buildings/doak.html |website=projects.ncsu.edu |accessdate=12 August 2018}} In 2013, the Wolfpack ranked 33rd among [[List of NCAA Division I baseball programs|Division I baseball programs]] in attendance, averaging 1,994 per home game.{{cite web |last=Cutler |first=Tami |title=2013 Division I Baseball Attendance - Final Report |url=http://www.sportswriters.net/ncbwa/news/2013/attendance130611.pdf |work=Sportswriters.net |publisher=NCBWA |accessdate=July 20, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6IGG6kpVy?url=http://www.sportswriters.net/ncbwa/news/2013/attendance130611.pdf |archivedate=July 20, 2013 |date=June 11, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In 2014, the Wolfpack ranked 45th in attendance, averaging 1,344 per home game.{{Cite web|title = http://www.sportswriters.net/ncbwa/news/2014/attendance140331.pdf|url = http://www.sportswriters.net/ncbwa/news/2014/attendance140331.pdf|website = www.sportswriters.net|accessdate = 2015-06-04}} The student section of the grandstands along the [[third base]] line is known as Avent's Army. It is named for NC State baseball coach [[Elliott Avent]].{{cite web |title=Sign Up for Avent's Army |url=http://www.gopack.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/031009aab.html |work=Go Pack |accessdate=16 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60z2ubIB8?url=http://www.gopack.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/031009aab.html |archivedate=2011-08-16 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.gopack.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=9200&ATCLID=518479 Doak Field page on GoPack.com]{{dead link|date=December 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{North Carolina State University}} {{NC State Wolfpack baseball navbox}} {{Atlantic Coast Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{North Carolina NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} {{Triangle sports venues}} [[Category:NC State Wolfpack sports venues]] [[Category:NC State Wolfpack baseball]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Raleigh, North Carolina]] [[Category:Baseball venues in North Carolina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1966]] [[Category:1966 establishments in North Carolina]]

{{Infobox sport | image = Fiestas patronales del Mercado Central de Piñas.jpg | imagesize = 260px | caption = An ecua-volley game in [[Piñas Canton|Piñas, Ecuador]] | union = FEDENALIGAS | nickname = Boly | first = unknown | registered = | clubs = | contact = | team = 3 player | mgender = team, | category = Indoor, Outdoor, Beach | ball = ''mikasa ft-5'' soccer ball | olympic = No | website = }}
'''Ecua-volley''' is a [[Volleyball variations|variant of volleyball]] invented and played in [[Ecuador]]. Its official name is '''Ecuavoley''', however it can be informally be called '''ecuavolley''', '''ecuavoly''', '''ecuabol''', or simply '''boly'''. Its popularity has also spread to [[Colombia|Colombians]], the United States, and Europe.
==History== The beginning of this variant volleyball game is unclear. It is believed that some type of game similar to this already existed prior to European contact. <ref>http://tuecuavoley.com/ecuavoley-detalle-breve-historia.html</ref> While it is adherent that [[Volleyball]] was invented in 1895, and the first world tournaments were held 1949, organized tournaments of Ecuavolley were held in 1958, suggesting it could not have spread throughout the world that quickly, which would mean that the national volley game was developed independently and had a [[convergent evolution]]. <ref>http://tuecuavoley.com/ecuavoley-detalle-breve-historia.html</ref> Ecuavoley tournaments in neighborhoods were held by different organization since 1944.
== Rules of the game == The setup of the game is similar to volleyball, with a few key differences:<ref>https://www.plazadeportiva.com.ec/frontEnd/images/objetos/Reglamentos%20Ecuavolley%20.docx {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526102558/https://www.plazadeportiva.com.ec/frontEnd/images/objetos/Reglamentos%20Ecuavolley%20.docx |date=May 26, 2013 }}</ref><ref>http://www.fedenaligas.org/dp/index.php/reglamentos/ecuavoley</ref> * Each team is made up of three players: the setter (Spanish: ''colocador''), the flyer (''volador''), and the server (''servidor''). * The net is higher and tighter: 2.80 meters high and 60 centimeters wide. * The court is made of cement and has the same dimensions: 18 meters long and 9 meters wide. * The game is played with a ''mikasa ft-5'' soccer ball. * Games consist of two sets of 15 points. If both teams agree, they can alternatively play two sets of 12 points with the option of a third tie-breaking set. * The ball can be held each time it is received, as long as the holding lasts less than one second.
== Gameplay == The flyer plays behind the setter and server, and runs quickly from one side to another recovering balls. Usually the flyer recovers the ball for the server. The server sets the ball in the air so that the setter can pass the ball over the net. The setter places the ball on the opposite court in a strategic manner, in an attempt to deceive the other team of where it will land. The referee is called the judge.
==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.apdpecuador.com/articulo/3/124 Reglamento Campeonato Nacional de Ecuavóley] {{es icon}} * [http://www.cieepi.ec/index.php?option=com_remository&Itemid=66&func=fileinfo&id=42 Reglamentos juegos CIEEPI] {{es icon}} * [http://tuecuavoley.com/ecuavoley-detalle-breve-historia.html tuecuavoley.com] {{es icon}} * [http://utpltv.uvigo.es/serial/261.html Mediateca-Ecuavóley] {{es icon}} * [https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=appinventor.ai_andres_almeidab.ecuaVoley10&hl=en Ecuavoley App]

revision.text:
{{Infobox sport overview | boxwidth = 250 | title = Ice hockey in Japan | image = |caption= | imagesize = 240px | image_alt = | union = [[Japan Ice Hockey Federation]] | country = Japan | sport = ice hockey | noncountry = | teamlabel1 = | nationalteam = [[Japan men's national ice hockey team|Men's national team]];
[[Japan women's national ice hockey team|Women's national team]] | teamlabel2 = | repteam = | nickname = | first = | registered = | clubs = | national_list = [[Asia League Ice Hockey]] | intl_list = [[IIHF World Championships]]
[[Ice hockey at the Olympics|Winter Olympics]]
[[World Cup of Hockey|World Cup]] | match = | league = }} '''Ice hockey''' is a minor sport that is gaining popularity in '''Japan'''.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB887163678733471000 |title='Samurai' Boost Japanese Hockey |website=Wsj.com |date=1998-02-11 |accessdate=2016-10-18}}{{cite news|author= |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/hockey/cwhls-japanese-skaters-driven-by-passion-for-olympic-hockey-podium/article28066604/ |title=CWHL’s Japanese skaters driven by passion for Olympic hockey podium |publisher=The Globe and Mail |date= |accessdate=2016-10-15}}{{cite web|author=Bob Birge |url=http://www.thehour.com/sports/article/Former-Oiler-Terai-adjusting-to-hockey-and-life-8269284.php |title=Former Oiler Terai adjusting to hockey and life in Japan |publisher=The Hour |date=2013-03-25 |accessdate=2016-10-18}} [[Baseball]] and [[Association football|football]] (soccer) have dominated Japanese sports for decades, but ice hockey has been less popular in Japan since its founding in the 1920s.{{cite web|url=https://www.nhl.com/news/former-nhlers-find-hockey-adventure-in-japan/c-371001 |title=Former NHLers find hockey adventure in Japan |publisher=NHL.com |date= |accessdate=2016-10-15}} It is governed by the [[Japan Ice Hockey Federation]] == National and International Competitions == === Japan Ice Hockey League=== {{main|Japan Ice Hockey League}} The [[Japan Ice Hockey League]] (JIHL) was the national league in the country from 1966-2004, when it folded in favor of the international [[Asia League Ice Hockey|Asia League]]. Only Japanese teams were allowed to compete, and there were only six teams at any time in the league.{{cite web |title=JIHL league archives |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091122171009/http://www.jihf.or.jp/jihl/index-e.htm |website=www.jihf.or.jp |accessdate=4 November 2018}} ===All Japan Ice Hockey Championship=== {{main|All Japan Ice hockey Championship}} Since 1933, a cup competition, the [[All Japan Ice hockey Championship]] has been held, in which four teams compete. It has been held annually since the 1930s and is one of the oldest sporting competitions in the country. A women’s counterpart has been held since 1982.{{cite web |title=Eurohockey All Japan |url=http://www.eurohockey.com/league/1286-all-japan-ice-hockey-championship.html |website=www.eurohockey.com |accessdate=4 November 2018}} ===International Competitions=== Japan has men’s, women’s and junior national teams. The Japan women's national team qualified for the [[Ice hockey at the 2014 Winter Olympics|2014 Winter Olympics]] in [[Sochi]]{{cite web|url=https://www.olympic.org/news/women-s-ice-hockey-team-smile-japan-chase-olympic-dream |title=Women’s ice hockey team "Smile Japan" chase Olympic dream - Olympic News |publisher=Olympic.org |date= |accessdate=2016-10-15}}{{cite web|author=Samer Kalaf |url=http://deadspin.com/japans-womens-hockey-team-is-the-lovable-underdog-of-1519969657 |title=Japan's Women's Hockey Team Is The Lovable Underdog Of The Olympics |publisher=Deadspin.com |date=2013-12-18 |accessdate=2016-10-15}}{{cite web|last=Meadows |first=Mark |url=http://blogs.reuters.com/sport/2009/04/01/ice-hockey-japans-bunnies-boiled-by-economic-crisis/ |title=Ice hockey-Japan’s ‘Bunnies’ boiled by economic crisis |publisher=Blogs.reuters.com |date=2009-04-01 |accessdate=2016-10-15}}{{cite news|last=Watanabe |first=Tadashi |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2013/08/26/national/womens-ice-hockey-team-banking-on-sochi/#.WAYwfdKkoT8 |title=Women's ice hockey team banking on Sochi |newspaper=[[The Japan Times]] |date= |accessdate=2016-10-18}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/sport/olympics/2013/12/japan-ice-hockey-women-chase-olympic-dream-2013121811224115513.html |title=Japan's ice hockey women chase Olympic dream |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2013-12-18 |accessdate=2016-10-18}} and the [[Ice hockey at the 2018 Winter Olympics|2018 Winter Olympics]] in [[PyeongChang]], [[South Korea]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Asia topic|Ice hockey in}} [[Category:Ice hockey in Japan]] {{icehockey-stub}} {{Japan-sport-stub}}

[[Wad Madani]], [[Sudan]] | capacity = 5,000 | chairman = | manager = [[Tariq Amed Adm]]| league = [[Sudan Premier League]] | season = 2011 | position = 12th| pattern_la1=_whiteborder|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1=_whiteborder| leftarm1=177245|body1=177245|rightarm1=177245|shorts1=FFFFFF|socks1=177245| pattern_la2=_whiteborder|pattern_b2=|pattern_ra2=_whiteborder| leftarm2=FFFFFF|body2=FFFFFF|rightarm2=FFFFFF|shorts2=FFFFFF|socks2=177245| }} '''Jazeerat Al-Feel Sports Club''' ({{lang-ar|نادي جزيرة الفيل الرياضي}}) is a [[Sudan]]ese [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Wad Madani]]. {{Infobox football biography | name = Muddi | fullname = Mahmoud El-Hajj | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1987|2|13}} | height = 1.75 m | birth_place = [[Denmark]] | currentclub = | clubnumber = | position = [[Midfielder (association football)|Midfielder]] | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Aalborg Chang]] | years1 = 2005–2007 | years2 = 2007–2009 | years3 = 2009–2010 | clubs1 = [[AaB Fodbold|AaB Aalborg]] | clubs2 = [[FC Hjørring]] | clubs3 = [[AaB Fodbold|AaB Aalborg II]] | caps1 = 0 | caps2 = 28 | caps3 = 7 | goals1 = 0 | goals2 = 8 | goals3 = 5 }} '''Mahmoud El-Hajj''' ({{lang-ar|محمود الحاج}}; born February 13, 1987) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] of [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] and [[State of Palestine|Palestinian]] descent. He had resigned in 2007, but later he returned to the career due to [[Giuseppe Giannini]]'s calls.
== Early life == He was born to [[State of Palestine|Palestinian]]-[[Lebanon|Lebanese]] parents who came to [[Denmark]] from [[Lebanon]].<ref>[http://www.playerhistory.com/player/91962/ Mahmoud El-Hajj - Playerhistory.com]</ref>
== Career== Nicknamed '''Muddi''', he is a [[Denmark|Danish]] forward, who played for the [[Danish 2nd Division]] side [[FC Hjørring]] and for the [[Aalborg]]-based football clubs, [[Aalborg Chang]] and [[AaB Fodbold|AaB Aalborg and player of the year 2004]].

This gives the Rockets [[List of National Basketball Association longest winning streaks|the second-longest winning streak]] in NBA history, trailing only the 33-game streak of the [[1971–72 NBA season|1971–72]] [[Los Angeles Lakers]]. {{infobox country at games | NOC = MGL | NOCname = [[Mongolian National Olympic Committee]] | games = Summer Olympics | year = 1976 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = {{url|www.olympic.mn }} {{mn icon}} | location = [[Montreal]] | competitors = 33 | sports = 6 | flagbearer = [[Zevegiin Oidov]] | rank = 34 | gold = 0 | silver = 1 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }}
'''[[Mongolia]]''' competed at the '''[[1976 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada.
==Results by event==
===[[Archery at the 1976 Summer Olympics|Archery]]=== In the second time they competed in archery at the Olympics, Mongolia entered two men and two women. Their highest placing competitor was again [[Natjav Dariimaa]], this time at 22nd place in the women's competition. Dariimaa was the only Olympic veteran for Mongolia in 1976.
'''Women's Individual Competition''': * [[Natjav Dariimaa]] — 2209 points (→ 22nd place) * [[Gombosure Enkhtaivan]] — 2156 points (→ 24th place)
'''Men's Individual Competition''': * [[Niamtseren Biambasuren]] — 2256 points (→ 28th place) * [[Tserendorjin Dagvadorj]] — 2179 points (→ 32nd place)
===[[Boxing at the 1976 Summer Olympics|Boxing]]=== '''Men's Light Flyweight (– 48 kg)''' * [[Serdamba Batsuk]] *# First Round — Defeated [[Enrique Rodríguez (boxer)|Enrique Rodríguez]] (ESP), RSC-3 *# Second Round — Lost to [[György Gedó]] (HUN), 0:5
===[[Wrestling at the 1976 Summer Olympics|Wrestling]]=== '''Men's Freestyle (– 62 kg)''' * [[Zevegiin Oidov]] — Won the silver medal.
==References== *[http://www.la84foundation.org/5va/reports_frmst.htm Official Olympic Reports] *[http://www.olympic.org/uk/athletes/results/search_r_uk.asp International Olympic Committee results database]

revision.text:
{{short description|Comorian association football player}} {{Infobox football biography
|name= Nazarali Issa |fullname= Nazarali Issa Ramadhani |birth_date= 19 November 1990 |birth_place= [[Comoros]] |position= [[Forward (association football)|Attacker]] |years1= |clubs1= [[Coin Nord de Mitsamiouli]] |years2= |clubs2= [[Cercle de Joachim SC]] |years3= 2016-20xx |clubs3= [[SS Capricorne]] |years4= 2017- |clubs4= [[Trois Bassins FC]] |nationalyears1= 2008-20xx |nationalteam1= [[Comoros national football team|Comoros]]<ref>[https://comorosfootball269.blogspot.com/2015/08/yes-we-can-2017-retour-de-nazarali-en.html YES WE CAN 2017 : Retour de Nazarali en équipe A - Naza is back !!] Comoros Football 269</ref> |nationalcaps1= 5+ |nationalgoals1= 0+ }}
'''Nazarali Issa''' (born 19 November 1990 in [[Comoros]]) is a [[Comoros|Comorian]] footballer.
==Career==
===Mauritius===
Achieving a transfer to [[Cercle de Joachim SC]] prior to spring 2013,<ref>[http://www.comores-infos.net/lattaquant-international-comorien-nazarali-issa-sest-envole-pour-rejoindre-la-premiere-division-mauricienne/ L’attaquant international comorien Nazarali Issa s’est envolé pour rejoindre la première division mauricienne] Comores Infos</ref> Issa contributed a hat-trick as the ''Curepipiens'' eliminated [[AS Port-Louis 2000]] from the 2013 [[Mauritian Cup]].<ref>[https://www.lemauricien.com/article/football-mfa-cup-8es-finale-cerlce-joachim-elimine-l-aspl-2000/ FOOTBALL MFA CUP (8ES DE FINALE) : Le Cerlce de Joachim élimine l’ASPL 2000] Le Mauricien</ref>
===Reunion===
Putting four past AS 12ème Km at the [[2016–17 Coupe de France Preliminary Rounds|2016-17 Coupe de France]] with [[SS Capricorne]], the Comorian stated that the style in Mauritius was less technical compared to Reunion.<ref>[https://www.clicanoo.re/node/375330 "Là pour marquer des buts"] Clicanoo.re</ref> Pulling off a deal with [[Trois-Bassins FC|Trois-Bassins]] a year later, he chalked up three goals in his first two fixtures, including a double to fell [[AS Saint-Louisienne]] 2-0<ref>[https://www.clicanoo.re/Sport/Article/2017/08/20/Nazarali-cest-bien-lui_486116 Nazarali, c'est bien lui] Clicanoo.re</ref> before bring up his tally to four in as many rounds.<ref>[https://www.clicanoo.re/Sport/Article/2017/09/10/Nazarali-fait-son-nid_489634 Nazarali fait son nid] Clicanoo.re</ref> However, he picked dup an injury as November 2017 got underway.<ref>[https://www.clicanoo.re/Sport/Article/2017/11/05/Trois-Bassins-FC-JS-Saint-Pierroise-La-vie-sans-Nazarali_498993 Trois-Bassins FC - JS Saint-Pierroise : La vie sans Nazarali] Clicanoo.re</ref>
==Personal life==
His father dying on the 29th of July 2014, Comorian sports media blog eliedjouma.centerblog.net offered their commiserations to him as well as his family.<ref>[http://eliedjouma.centerblog.net/2791-deuil-nazarali-issa-a-perdu-son-papa Deuil : Nazarali Issa a perdu son papa] eliedjouma - Centerblog</ref>
{{Comoros-footy-bio-stub}} == References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using<ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2011}} {{Motorsport venue | Name = North Arm Speedway | Nicknames = The Place Where Champions Now Gather | Image = | Location = Grand Trunkway, [[Gillman, South Australia|Gillman]], [[South Australia]] 5013 | Broke_ground = | Opened = 26 July 1981 | Closed = 1997 | Coordinates = {{coord|34|49|25|S|138|31|21|E|display=it}} | Owner = [[Government of South Australia]] | Operator = Speedway Riders' Association of South Australia Inc. | Construction_cost = | Architect = | Former_names = | Events = [[Individual Speedway Australian Championship|Australian Solo Championship]]
[[Australian Under-21 Individual Speedway Championship|Australian Under-21 Solo Championship]]
[[South Australian Individual Speedway Championship|South Australian Solo Championship]]
South Australian [[Sidecar speedway|Sidecar]] Championship
[[Jack Young (speedway rider)#Jack Young Solo Cup|Jack Young Memorial Cup]]
Kevin O'Connell Memorial
Harry Denton Memorial Shield | Capacity = 5,000 | Layout1 = Speedway | Surface = [[Dolomite]] and shale | Miles_first = True | Length_mi = 0.173 | Length_km = 0.280 | Banking = | Record_time = | Record_driver = | Record_team = | Record_year = | Record_class = }} '''North Arm Speedway''' was the first dedicated [[motorcycle speedway]] ever built in [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]] and was located in the [[industrial suburb]] of [[Gillman, South Australia|Gillman]]. It was run by the Speedway Riders' Association of South Australia and ran from 1981 until its forced closure in 1997. ==History== ===Early Years=== North Arm Speedway was South Australia's first dedicated senior Solo and Sidecar track. Previous tracks (other than the [[Adelaide Showgrounds|Wayville Showgrounds]] in the late 1920s and early 1930s which ran before car speedway became popular) in both Adelaide and around the state had generally catered to both bikes and cars. The speedway was opened on Sunday 26 July 1981, by the Speedway Riders' Association on land owned by the [[Government of South Australia|South Australian Government]]. Following the closure of [[Rowley Park Speedway]] in April 1979, the only [[Dirt track racing]] venue in Adelaide was the new [[Speedway City|Speedway Park]], which has a clay surface, something that suited the increasingly popular car racing, but not motorcycle speedway. Despite the bikes racing in the early years at Speedway Park, the nearest speedway to Adelaide which suited bike racing was some 80 km away at the [[Riverview Speedway]] in [[Murray Bridge]], which during the speedway season (generally October to April) only ran meetings every second Saturday night. With many of South Australia's riders based in Adelaide, the decision was made to build a motorcycle only venue in Adelaide with a [[Dolomite]] surface where weekly meetings could be run. The track itself was approximately {{convert|280|m|yd|abbr=off}} in length, which while considered small by Australian track standards (when it was built, most Aussie speedways were usually 350-550m in length as most run cars as well as bikes with Speedway Park itself being {{convert|430|m|yd|abbr=off}} long), it was roughly the same length as most tracks in [[Speedway in the United Kingdom|Britain]] where most of the top riders rode professionally. The safety fence was a 2m high chain mesh fence on top of a 1 ft high wooden retaining fence. Lights were eventually installed for night meetings in 1985, although spectator capacity was only around 5,000 (more with extra seating for Australian Championship meetings). Due to North Arm's relatively small spectator capacity, and its lack of lights for night racing, both the [[Australian Sidecar Speedway Championship|Australian Sidecar Championship]] and the [[Australian Individual Speedway Championship|Australian Solo Championship]] were awarded to Speedway Park with its capacity to comfortably hold over 10,000 spectators in both 1982 and 1983 respectively. ===Move to Friday Nights=== When it first opened North Arm Speedway held regular Sunday afternoon meetings so as not to compete with Speedway Park which ran Friday nights and had the bikes on the program, and also to avoid clashing with meetings at the Riverview Speedway. South Australian riders would regularly race three days per week at home, something most experienced when racing in the British Leagues during the Australian winter months. After the 1984/85 season, bikes were off the program at Speedway Park following safety concerns after the death of rider Kevin O'Connell on 25 January 1985. O'Connell had been killed after he hit the speedway's concrete retaining wall which offered no protection to riders or passengers. With the bikes no longer competing at Speedway Park, lights were installed at North Arm in 1985 and the speedway began holding regular Friday night meetings from 1985/86 which lasted until the speedway's closure. During the winter of 1986 the pits at North Arm were also re-located. Originally they were outside the back straight but were moved to outside of the front straight behind the control tower (which also incorporated the announcers box). The old pits became car parking while Turn 3 for the solo's (Turn 2 for the sidecars) became known as the Old Pits Corner. ===Championships and International Meetings=== From 1983 until it closed in 1997 North Arm became the regular host of the [[South Australian Individual Speedway Championship|South Australian Solo]] and [[Sidecar speedway|Sidecar]] championships, hosting the Solo title 10 times. The only other tracks to host the SA Solo title during this period were the [[Westline Speedway]] in [[Whyalla]] (1986/87) and Riverview Speedway (1984/85, 1987/88, 1990/91). North Arm hosted the [[1992 Australian Individual Speedway Championship|1992 Australian Solo Championship]], where a capacity crowd of over 6,000 fans saw [[Leigh Adams]] from [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] win the first of a record 10 national championships (a temporary grandstand was erected on the outside of turn 1 for the expected attendance). Adams set a track record in the 2nd heat of the night with a time of 58.74 seconds for the 4 lap race. The record he broke had been set in Heat 1 of the championship by reigning South Aussie Champ [[Craig Hodgson]] who won in a time of 59.11 seconds. Leigh Adams won with 14 points from North Arm's own [[Shane Parker (speedway rider)|Shane Parker]] on 13 and [[Queensland]]'s [[Mark Carlson (speedway rider)|Mark Carlson]] third on 11 points. This meeting also saw the crash which almost ended the career of Australia's former World #3 from [[1990 Individual Speedway World Championship|1990]], [[Todd Wiltshire]] who suffered a multiple back injuries and broken pelvis which force him to retire at age 23 though he did make a successful comeback in 1997. Wiltshire, battling with [[Jason Lyons]] for the lead going into the last turn of Heat 3, tried a pass on the outside and went down, sliding into the wooden safety fence which broke around a light pole (placed outside the fence) on impact in the old pit corner. Unfortunately during its 16-year life span, North Arm was never awarded the right to host the Australian Sidecar Championship, although it did host some of Australia's richest Sidecar meetings. North Arm Speedway's spectator capacity was pushed to the limit on a number of occasions including test Matches between [[Australia national speedway team|Australia]] with riders such as [[Phil Crump]], Todd Wiltshire, Leigh Adams and local riders Shane Parker, Scott Norman and [[Shane Bowes]] taking on visiting 'teams' such as a "Rest of the World" team in 1990 including [[Gary Havelock]] of [[England]], [[Mitch Shirra]] of [[New Zealand]], and [[Shawn Moran]] of the [[United States]] (while the injured [[Sam Ermolenko]] was guest commentator on the night). In 1991 Australia faced a powerful [[Sweden national speedway team|Swedish]] team led by [[1990 Individual Speedway World Championship|1990 World Champion]] [[Per Jonsson]], former dual [[Individual Ice Racing World Championship|Ice Racing World Champion]] Erik Stenlund, as well as 1990 World finalists [[Jimmy Nilsen]] and [[Henrik Gustafsson]] and [[1988 Individual Speedway Junior World Championship|1988 World Under-21 Champion]] [[Peter Nahlin]] (who was the Swedish reserve on the night). The Swede's also had in their riding lineup a young rider who was not only the reigning [[Speedway Swedish Individual Championship|Swedish Champion]], but the rider would go on equal [[Ivan Mauger]]'s six [[Speedway World Championship]]s, the great [[Tony Rickardsson]]. Both the 1990 and 1991 test matches attracted 4,000 and 4,800 fans respectively, well up on previous crowd figures for the speedway. It was the success of those two international meetings which led to the speedway being awarded the 1992 Australian Solo Championship. The 1990/91 season also saw the first, and so far only tour of Australia by the official [[Russia national speedway team|USSR]] team, who while not facing Australia in a test, faced state teams and various other 'select' teams while on tour. They faced a South Australian Select team in their visit to North Arm on 28 December 1990 with the locals, strengthened by 'ring-ins' Dennis Löfqvist from [[Sweden]] and [[David Norris (speedway rider)|David Norris]] from [[England]] (resident North Arm international riders) defeating the Russians 53-37 in a match closer than the score suggests. Actual local riders Shane Bowes (team captain) and Shane Parker top scored for the 'SA' with 13 and 8 points respectively while [[Oleg Kurguskin]] with 11 and the late Rif Saitgareev with 10 points top scored for the Russians. During its lifetime North Arm was also the Australian base for various international riders racing in the Australian Speedway season with riders such as [[Shawn Moran]] ([[United States of America|USA]]), Vesa Ylinen of [[Finland]], Dennis Löfqvist from Sweden and David Norris from England all basing themselves in Adelaide. North Arm was also the Australian base for two future [[Speedway World Championship|Speedway World Champions]]. Twenty-year-old Gary Havelock from England (the [[1992 Individual Speedway World Championship|1992 World Champion]]) spent the 1987/88 Australian season based at North Arm, while [[2010 Speedway Grand Prix|2010 World Champion]] [[Tomasz Gollob]] from [[Poland]] (along with his brother [[Jacek Gollob|Jacek]] who made a number of appearances), made North Arm his Aussie home during 1994/95. While North Arm had its fair share of accidents, sometimes resulting in serious injury, no competitor was ever killed at the speedway or later as the result of a crash. ==Closing== Following the 1996/97 Australian Speedway season (generally run between October and April), North Arm Speedway was closed when the South Australian Government reclaimed the land that the speedway was located on. This left Adelaide without an operating motorcycle speedway for the first time since 1926 when racing was first held at the [[Adelaide Showgrounds|Wayville Showground]]. Most of North Arm's track surface was then moved less than 2 km away to the new [[Gillman Speedway]] to form the base of a {{convert|213|m|yd|abbr=off}} track that was used for daytime practice meetings until a larger {{convert|400|m|yd|abbr=off}} track was built for race meetings before the current {{convert|300|m|yd|abbr=off}} track was opened in 2000. Even though Friday night meetings at the track were held in summer, North Arm could actually be cold when the wind was blowing from the north or west (the track was located close to the marshlands and adjacent to the [[Port River]] and the [[Gulf St Vincent]]). The speedway also had spectator facilities which could be described average at best. Despite this, North Arm Speedway is fondly remembered by those who either rode there or were regular spectators. ==Present Day== Today the site of North Arm Speedway shows nothing of its past as a speedway as industrial buildings now occupy the land. The last remnants of the speedway were removed in mid-2004 when what was left of the track itself was cleared and building starting in mid-2005. When looking on [[Google Earth]] at historic photos the start/finish line of the speedway was on the Grand Trunkway (road) side of the track, with the pit area located between the front straight and the road. Car parking for the speedway was in the area to the north of the track. ==Australian Championships== ===Australian Solo Championship=== * [[1992 Australian Individual Speedway Championship|1992]] - {{flagicon|Victoria}} [[Leigh Adams]] - 14pts ===Australian Under-21 Championship=== * 1988 - {{flagicon|Victoria}} [[Leigh Adams]] * 1996 - {{flagicon|South Australia}} [[Ryan Sullivan]] {{Infobox football club | clubname = Panamá Viejo F.C. | image = [[Image:Panama Viejo 1.png|Logo]] | fullname = Panamá Viejo Fútbol Club | nickname = ''Los Cangrejeros'' | founded = 1978 | dissolved = 2001 | ground = [[Estadio Javier Cruz 'Artes y Oficios']]
[[Panama City, Panama]] | capacity = 2,500 | chairman = | manager = | league = [[ANAPROF]] | season = | position = | pattern_la1=_green_shoulders|pattern_b1=_greenshoulders|pattern_ra1=_green_shoulders | leftarm1=FFFF00|body1=FFFF00|rightarm1=FFFF00|shorts1=FFFFFF|socks1=009900| }} '''Panamá Viejo F.C.''' was a [[Panamanian]] [[association football|football]] team founded in 1978 and based in [[Panamá Viejo]], [[Panama]]. The club was a regular participant in the [[ANAPROF]] (now [[Liga Panameña de Fútbol]]), and in their final season the ''Cangrejeros'' won the [[ANAPROF 2000-01|2000–01]] championship. They succumbed to financial problems at the end of 2001. ==History== Panamá Viejo was founded in 1978, and become a frequent participant in the [[ANAPROF]]. During the [[ANAPROF 2000-01|2000–01]] season, they enjoyed their most memorable success, reaching the championship final for the very first time. There, they met [[Tauro F.C.]], the defending champions and aiming at their fourth championship in five years. Panama Viejo, however, entered with one of their strongest teams ever. Theirs was a lineup that featured [[Panama national football team|Panamanian internationals]] like tall striker [[Anel Canales]], winger [[Víctor Herrera Piggott|Víctor Herrera]], attacking midfielder [[Ricardo Phillips]], midfielder [[Blas Pérez]], young defensive midfielder [[Juan de Dios Pérez]], and keeper [[Óscar McFarlane]]. They were managed by [[Gary Stempel]]. The final match between Panamá Viejo and Tauro FC went down as one of the greatest finals in the history of [[ANAPROF]]. Tauro scored first, but thanks to two Erick Martinez goals Panamá Viejo was able to go ahead 3-1. Tauro rallied to equalize the tie at 3-3, but Rodney Ramos's extra time penalty won the match for Panamá Viejo.[http://elsiglo.com/deportes/malos-recuerdos/23452499 Malos recuerdos] – El Siglo {{es|icon}} It was Panamá Viejo's only title. The club was family owned, and when they were unable to find a sponsor for the ensuing season, the owners decided to seek a merger. Ironically, they merged with Tauro FC. Unfortunately for the ''Cangrejeros'', in 2001 they suffered financial problems and they were forced to merged with [[Tauro F.C.|Tauro]] whereby they ceased to exist.[http://www.critica.com.pa/cangrejeros-de-panama-viejo-gloria-del-futbol-286493 ‘Cangrejeros’ de Panamá Viejo: Gloria del fútbol] – Crítica {{es|icon}}[http://impresa.prensa.com/deportes/Finalmente-Panama-Viejo-decidio-Tauro_0_587191282.html Finalmente Panamá Viejo se decidió por el Tauro] – La Prensa {{es|icon}} [[File:Panama Viejo (pre 2000).png|thumb|right|Panamá Viejo's crest before winning the [[ANAPROF 2000-01|2000–01]] championship]] ==Honors== *'''[[ANAPROF]]: 1''' ::[[2000–01 ANAPROF|2000–01]] ==Notable former players== {{col-begin-small}} {{col-2}} *{{flagicon|PAN}} [[Alberto Blanco (footballer)|Alberto Blanco]] *{{flagicon|PAN}} [[Anel Canales]] *{{flagicon|PAN}} [[Víctor Herrera Piggott|Víctor Herrera]] *{{flagicon|PAN}} [[Juan Jesús Julio]] *{{flagicon|PAN}} [[Óscar McFarlane]] {{col-2}} *{{flagicon|PAN}} [[Blas Pérez]] *{{flagicon|PAN}} [[Juan de Dios Pérez]] *{{flagicon|PAN}} [[Ricardo Phillips]] *{{flagicon|PAN}} [[Gary Ramos]] *{{flagicon|PAN}} [[Rodney Ramos]] {{col-end}} ==Notable former managers== *{{flagicon|ENG}}{{flagicon|PAN}} [[Gary Stempel]] (1998–2001)[http://wvw.nacion.com/ln_ee/2000/febrero/16/deportes7.html Un joven rival•Panamá Viejo es un equipo joven y entusiasta, guiado por un entrenador que conoce a la perfección las virtudes y los defectos de sus jugadores] – Nación {{es|icon}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *http://www.rsssf.com/tablesp/panamachamp.html {{DEFAULTSORT:Panama Viejo F.C.}} [[Category:Defunct football clubs in Panama]] [[Category:1978 establishments in Panama]] [[Category:2001 disestablishments in Panama]] {{Panama-footyclub-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Colt McCoy on a quarterback keeper vs Rice - 2006-09-16.jpg|thumb|280px|[[Colt McCoy]] runs a keeper.]] A '''quarterback keeper''' or '''keeper''' in [[American football]] is a designed play in which the [[quarterback]] does not [[Forward pass|pass]] or [[Handoff (American football)|hand off]] the ball to another player and instead rushes forward with it in an effort to gain yardage. The play typically is run in instances where only a few yards are needed to gain a first down or [[touchdown]], due to the threat of injury to the quarterback and most quarterbacks' ineffectiveness at running the ball when compared with a [[running back]] or [[Fullback (American football)|fullback]]. This play differs from a [[quarterback scramble]] in that a scramble is an improvised play, while the keeper is a designed running play.
== References ==
* [http://brucey.net/nflab/howtoplay/offenser.html#_QK Definition of a quarterback keeper], definitions of running plays
== External links == * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5DeRyw8Yf44 Youtube video of a successful quarterback keeper]
{{Gridiron football plays}} [[Category:American football terminology]] [[Category:American football plays]]

[[File:RavenscraigMainEntrance.jpg|thumb|Main entrance to the facility]] {{Infobox venue | name = Ravenscraig Regional Sports Facility | nickname = | caption = Main entrance to the facility. | location = Ravenscraig Regional Sports Facility
Motherwell
North Lanarkshire
Scotland | coordinates = {{Coord|55|47|37.03|N|3|57|48.68|W|type:landmark|display=inline}} | opened = 30 September 2010 | closed = | demolished = | owner = North Lanarkshire Leisure[http://www.nlleisure.co.uk/detail.asp?PageID=106 Ravenscraig Sports Facility] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101109112606/http://www.nlleisure.co.uk/detail.asp?PageID=106 |date=9 November 2010 }}, North Lanarkshire Leisure | operator = [[Sportscotland]] | construction_cost = £30 Million (estimate) | architect = [[Populous (company)|Populous]][http://portfolio.populous.com/projects/ravenscraig.html Ravenscraig Sports Facility], Populous Official Website | former_names = | tenants = | seating_capacity = }} The '''Ravenscraig Regional Sports Facility''' is a public [[leisure centre]] that is located in the [[Ravenscraig]] area of [[Motherwell]], [[North Lanarkshire]], Scotland. ==History== The sports facility first came to attention when plans were being drawn up to form a new town on the site of the former [[Ravenscraig steelworks]], which closed in 1992.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/glasgow_and_west/6183713.stm |title=£1.2bn Ravenscraig project starts |work=[[BBC News]] |date=15 December 2006 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} The sports facility project was given the go-ahead on November 2008.{{cite web |url=http://news.stv.tv/scotland/west-central/38461-new-sports-centre-to-be-built-at-ravenscraig/ |title=New sports centre to be built at Ravenscraig |work=[[STV (TV network)|STV Sport]] |date=7 November 2008 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} Work on the new facility got underway in mid-2009.{{cite web |url=http://www.motherwelltimes.co.uk/sport/New-year-start-for-Ravenscraig.4802497.jp |title=New year start for Ravenscraig sports facility |work=Motherwell Times |date=17 December 2008 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} However, the project was at the centre of serious funding issues between different companies and councils, and thus delayed the beginning of construction by one year.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/glasgow_and_west/7352416.stm |title=Fears over Ravenscraig Commitment |work=BBC News |date=18 April 2008 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} The building has been fully completed and was opened to the public on 4 October 2010. Before opening, there was a 24-hour charity football event on 30 September 2010. On 16 February 2011, [[Provost (civil)|Provost]] Tom Curley officially opened the facility, and it was estimated that over 100,000 people had used the facility for the first five months in operation.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-12495604 |title=New Ravenscraig sports centre attracts 100,000 people |work=BBC News |date=17 February 2011 |accessdate=2012-05-04}}{{cite web |url=http://news.stv.tv/scotland/west-central/229155-ravenscraig-centre-hosts-official-opening-ceremony/ |title=Ravenscraig centre hosts official opening ceremony |work=[[STV News]] |date=17 February 2011 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} ==Facilities== Some of the amenities that the facility includes are: * Full size indoor 3rd generation [[Artificial turf|synthetic]] [[football pitch]] with spectator seating ([[FIFA]] 2 star standard) * 135m indoor [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]] track with throws and jump areas, including [[high jump]], [[long jump]], [[triple jump]] and [[pole vault]]. Also included is a throw cage suitable for [[Javelin throw|javelin]], [[Hammer throw|hammer]] and [[discus]]. * Strength and conditioning area based within the athletics hall containing 5 [[Olympic Games|Olympic]] [[Olympic weightlifting|weightlifting]] platforms. * 9 court [[badminton]] sports hall with [[sprung floor]]ing and spectator seating * Fitness gym * Full-size outdoor 3rd generation synthetic football/rugby pitch (FIFA 2 star standard) * Six five-a-side 3rd generation synthetic floodlit football pitches * Two [[dance studio]]s with sprung flooring * [[Starbucks]] cafe * [[Sports injuries]] clinic * [[Drug testing]] area * Office facilities and meeting rooms There is also a [[jogging]] track completely surrounding the building that connects with the wider network of [[cycling]] and jogging paths throughout Ravenscraig and beyond. A mobile [[tennis court]] has been added for indoor and outdoor use, the first of its type in the [[United Kingdom|UK]].{{cite web |url=http://local.stv.tv/motherwell/sport/21058-boost-for-tennis-with-unique-pop-up-courts-at-ravenscraig/ |title=Boost for tennis with unique pop up courts at Ravenscraig |work=[[STV News]] |date=14 July 2011 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} ==Praise== The facility has, even before opening, received several positive commendations. One in particular was from the [[Scotland national football team|Scottish football team]] manager [[Craig Levein]], who said that the facility would benefit football and the local community.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-glasgow-west-11436406 |title=Levein backs new sports facility at Ravenscraig |work=BBC News |date=30 September 2010 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} Former [[First Minister of Scotland|First Minister]] [[Henry McLeish]] also admitted in part one of his report of [[Scottish football]] that facilities like Ravenscraig are important for the future of the national game.{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/scotland/8638920.stm |title=Major report demands changes to Scottish football |work=BBC Sport |date=23 April 2010 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} Also, former [[Commonwealth Games]] [[gold medalist]] [[Yvonne Murray]] says that the facility will benefit sport in Scotland, saying that it will boost the nations medal tally.{{cite web |url=http://www.wishawpress.co.uk/wishaw-sport/2010/10/06/ravenscraig-will-boost-our-medal-tally-says-murray-76495-27406383/ |title=Ravenscraig will boost our medal tally, says Murray |work=[[Wishaw Press]] |date=6 October 2010 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} In June 2011, First Minister [[Alex Salmond]] praised the facility, admitting that it will deliver a real and lasting legacy for Scotland and North Lanarkshire.{{cite web |url=http://www.hamiltonadvertiser.co.uk/hamilton-lanarkshire-sport/other-sport/2011/06/09/first-minister-visits-ravenscraig-facility-51525-28845097/ |title=First Minister visits Ravenscraig facility |work=Hamilton Advertiser |date=9 June 2011 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} On 13 October 2011, over a year after opening, it was revealed that the facility had attracted over 500,000 people,{{cite web |url=http://www.wishawpress.co.uk/wishaw-news/local-wishaw-news/wishaw-news/2011/10/12/ravenscraig-sports-centre-celebrates-500-000-visitors-in-first-year-76495-29576086/ |title=Ravenscraig sports centre celebrates 500,000 visitors in first year |work=Wishaw Press |date=12 October 2011 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} and by 27 June 2012, the visitor count had past the million mark.{{cite web |url=http://local.stv.tv/motherwell/news/108020-making-steps-towards-a-bright-new-future-for-ravenscraig/ |title=Making steps towards a bright new future for Ravenscraig |work=STV News |date=27 June 2012 |accessdate=2012-06-27}} ==Major events== The facility is being strongly considered as a training facility for the [[2012 Olympics]] in [[London]] and the [[2014 Commonwealth Games]] in [[Glasgow]].{{cite web |url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2007/10/30121839 |title=£29m for Ravenscraig sports complex |work=Scotland.gov.uk |date=30 October 2007 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} Ravenscraig regional facility was also the main facility for the 2011 [[International Children's Games]] that took place in [[Lanarkshire]], hosting the [[badminton]] and the [[athletics events]]. The facility has also been host to several major sporting events, such as the British Lightweight Boxing Title Fight and the [[2011 Premier League Snooker|Premier League Snooker tournament]].{{cite web |url=http://www.motherwelltimes.co.uk/sport/local-sport/ravenscraig_goes_potty_for_snooker_1_1831361 |title=Ravenscraig goes potty for snooker |work=Motherwell Times |date=7 September 2011 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} as well as several other events involving big names in British Sport.{{cite web |url=http://local.stv.tv/motherwell/news/27495-television-programme-recorded-at-ravenscraig/ |title=Television programme recorded at Ravenscraig |work=STV Sport |date=16 November 2011 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} In recent times, the facility has also been confirmed as one of six 2020 Football Performance Centres across Scotland.{{cite web |url=http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/scottish_fa_news.cfm?page=1957&newsCategoryID=4&newsID=9790 |title=Six 2020 Performance Centres open |work=[[Scottish Football Association]] |date=3 May 2012 |accessdate=2012-05-04}} On 27 June 2012, it was revealed that over 500 sporting events had been held in the facility. ==See also== Other indoor football facilities in Scotland: *[[Toryglen Regional Football Centre]] (Glasgow) *[[Oriam]] (Edinburgh) *[[Aberdeen University Sports Union#Aberdeen Sports Village|Aberdeen Sports Village]] (Aberdeen) ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100927190903/http://www.ravenscraig.co.uk/sports_facility.asp Regional Sports facility on Ravenscraig.co.uk] {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} {{Football venues in Scotland}} [[Category:Motherwell]] [[Category:2010 establishments in Scotland]] [[Category:Sports venues in North Lanarkshire]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2010]] [[Category:Football venues in Scotland]]
