{{Infobox football club | clubname = Sitra Cultural & Sports Club | image = [[File:Setra Club.png|Logo|100px]] | fullname = Sitra Cultural & Sports Club | nickname = | founded = {{Start date and age|1957}} | ground = [[Bahrain National Stadium]]
[[Sitra]], [[Bahrain]] | capacity = 70,000| | chairman = {{flagicon|Bahrain}} [[Ali Manssor Al-Sawad]] | Treasurer = {{flagicon|Bahrain}} [[Fuad Hassan]] Cup = [[Bahraini Premier League]] | season = 2006/07 | position = | pattern_la1 = | pattern_b1 = _unknown | pattern_ra1 = | leftarm1 = FFFFFF | body1 = FFFFFF | rightarm1 = FFFFFF | shorts1 = FFFFFF | socks1 = FFFFFF | pattern_la2 = | pattern_b2 = _unknown | pattern_ra2 = | leftarm2 = FFFFFF | body2 = FFFFFF | rightarm2 = FFFFFF | shorts2 = FFFFFF | socks2 = FFFFFF| }} '''Sitra Club''' ({{lang-ar| نادي سترة الثقافي والرياضي}}) is a [[Bahrain]]i sports club based in Sitra, established in 1957 located Sitra Village in Kingdom of Bahrain. The main activities are football and Basketball plays. Sitra Club also takes part in other sports like Body Building and Karate. Historically, Sitra Club won football and basketball championships. The Management: '''Chairman''': Mr. Ali Mansoor Al-Sawad, '''Under Secretary''': Mr. Essam Al-Jazeeri, '''The Treasurer''': Mr. Fuad Hassan, '''Football Head''': Mr. A. Ameer Salman, '''Basketball Head''': Mr. Sadiq Mahdi, '''Other Board Members''': Mr. Ebrahim Al-Khudran, Mr. Jaffar Al-Jazeeri and Mr. A. Jalil Al-Jarmal. '''Club Manager''': Mr. Mustafa Saad, '''Executive Secretary''': Mr. Hussain Al-Sanadi. ==External links== {{Empty section|date=March 2012}} {{Bahraini Premier League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Bahrain]] [[Category:Basketball teams in Bahrain]] [[Category:1957 establishments in Bahrain]] {{Bahrain-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox hockey team | team = Skautafélag Reykjavíkur | colour = blue | colour text = white | logo = | logosize = | city = [[Reykjavík]], [[Iceland]] | league = [[Icelandic Hockey League]] | conference = | division = | founded = 1873 | arena = Skautahöllin Laugardal | colours = blue, white, red
{{Color box|blue|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|white|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|red|border=darkgray}} | coach = | GM = | website = | name1 = | dates1 = | name2 = | dates2 = }} '''Skautafélag Reykjavíkur''', also known as '''SR''' for short, is an Icelandic sports club, founded in 1873 and based in [[Reykjavík]], [[Iceland]]. It is best known for its [[ice hockey]] teams that have played in the men's [[Icelandic Hockey League]] and the women's [[Úrvalsdeild kvenna (ice hockey)|Úrvalsdeild kvenna]]. ==Men's ice hockey== [[File:Skautafélag Reykjavíkur hockey team.JPG|thumb|right|SR players in 2015]] The club has won the [[Icelandic Hockey League]] six times, which is second only to [[Skautafelag Akureyrar]]. ===Achievements=== *[[Icelandic Hockey League|Icelandic champions]]: (5) 1999, 2000, 2006, 2007, 2009. ===Notable players=== *[[Kári Valsson]] *[[Ozan Sigurjónsson]] ==External links== * [http://www.skautafelag.is/ Official site] * [http://eurohockey.com/club/538-skautaflag-reykjavikur.html Team profile] on eurohockey.com {{DEFAULTSORT:Skautafelag Reykjavikur}} [[Category:Ice hockey teams in Iceland]] [[Category:Ice hockey clubs established in 1873]] [[Category:1873 establishments in Iceland]] [[Category:Icelandic Hockey League]] [[Category:Sport in Reykjavík]] {{Iceland-sport-stub}} {{Europe-icehockey-team-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Use Australian English|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox venue | name = BB Print Stadium Mackay | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | fullname = | former_names = | location = Cnr Casey Ave & Bridge Road, [[Mackay, Queensland|Mackay]], [[Queensland]] | coordinates = {{Coord|21|9|49|S|149|11|2|E|display=it}} | broke_ground = 2010 | built = 2011 | opened = {{Start date|df=yes|2011|08|20}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Mackay Regional Council]] | operator = | surface = Grass | cost = [[Australian dollar|A$]] 11.3 million | architect = Alan Griffith Architect | dimensions = | capacity = 12,200 {{cite news|last=Clare|first=Bianca|title=Work to start on new stadium|url=http://www.dailymercury.com.au/story/2009/08/07/work-start-new-stadium/|accessdate=7 August 2009|newspaper=The Daily Mercury}} | website = http://www.mackay.qld.gov.au/community/council_facilities2/stadium_mackay | tenants = [[Mackay Cutters]] ([[Queensland Cup|QLD Cup]]) (2011-present)
[[Whitsunday Miners FC|Whitsunday Miners]] ([[Queensland State League (association football)|QSL]]) (2011-present)
[[Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs]] ([[NRL]]) (2012–2013)
[[Queensland Country]] ([[National Rugby Championship]]) (2018) }} '''Stadium Mackay''', currently known as its [[Naming rights|sponsored name]] '''BB Print Stadium Mackay''', is a rectangular [[football]] stadium situated in [[Mackay, Queensland|Mackay]], [[Queensland]], [[Australia]]. The stadium is home to the Intrust Super Cup's Absolute Enterprises's [[Mackay Cutters]] and [[Queensland State League (association football)|Queensland State League]]'s [[Whitsunday Miners FC|Whitsunday Miners]]. The 2016 to 2020 naming rights deal is the first time a local business has been given naming rights to the stadium and was one of the deciding factors by Mackay Regional Council and CAS Ltd (the board overseeing BB Print Stadium Mackay). BB Print Stadium Mackay was previously known as Virgin Stadium Australia. ==Stadium== The 12,200 capacity stadium was funded by the [[Australian Government]] at a cost of 11.3 million and opened on 20 August 2011 at a [[Mackay Cutters]] home game.{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Tom|title=It's game on for Miners|url=http://www.dailymercury.com.au/story/2011/08/02/its-game-on-stadium-gates-to-open-early-for-miners/|accessdate=2 August 2011|newspaper=The Daily Mercury}} The stadium consists of a western grandstand that can accommodate 2,000 people including 10 corporate boxes, 6 corporate suites and broadcast box.{{cite news|last=Bastable|first=Kate|title=Countdown is on for kickoff|url=http://www.dailymercury.com.au/story/2011/06/08/countdown-is-on-for-kickoff/|accessdate=8 June 2011|newspaper=The Daily Mercury}} 2.5 million of the total 11.3 million cost of the stadium was spent on installing lighting that is of [[National Rugby League|NRL]] and television standard so that the stadium could possible host regular season [[National Rugby League|NRL]] matches.{{cite news|last=Newborn|first=Jamie|title=Light towers go up at stadium|url=http://www.dailymercury.com.au/story/2011/04/19/light-towers-go-up-at-stadium-mackay/|accessdate=19 April 2011|newspaper=The Daily Mercury}} On 1 March 2016 it was announced that the grounds would be renamed to BB Print Stadium Mackay after BB Print purchased the naming rights to the stadium.{{cite news|title=Virgin sponsors Stadium Mackay|url=http://www.dailymercury.com.au/story/2011/08/18/virgin-sponsors-stadium-mackay/|accessdate=18 August 2011|newspaper=The Daily Mercury}} On Sunday 24 June 2012, BB Print Stadium Mackay hosted its first NRL game when the 2nd placed [[Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs]] played a 'home' game at the venue against the ladder leading [[Melbourne Storm]] in Round 16 of the [[2012 NRL season]], the NRL's '''Women in League Round'''. In front of a ground record crowd of 11,876 the Bulldogs defeated the Storm 20-4 with Mackay product [[Ben Barba]] setting up one of the tries of the season for Bulldogs team mate [[Josh Morris (rugby league)|Josh Morris]]. Barba fielded a Storm kick only one metre from the dead ball line, then evaded his opposition and ran 70 metres down field before centre kicking for Morris to score next to the posts for what was a 109-metre try. The stadium hosted its second NRL game on 7 July 2013 when the Bulldogs hosted the [[Newcastle Knights]] in Round 17 of the [[2013 NRL season]]. The stadium hosted a pre-season match between [[A-League]] clubs [[Brisbane Roar]] and [[Sydney FC]] on 16 September 2012.{{cite news|title=Brisbane to roar into our stadium|url=http://www.dailymercury.com.au/story/2012/08/01/brisbane-to-roar-into-our-stadium-soccer-football/|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=The Daily Mercury}} On the 15th of September 2018 BB Print Stadium hosted professional Rugby Union when [[Queensland Country]] defeated [[Fijian Drua]] 52-22 in a [[National Rugby Championship]] match in front of 1200 fans. BB Print Stadium Mackay is home to the Intrust Super Cup's Absolute Enterprises Mackay Cutters and has also hosted; NRL games, the internationally televised Professional Bull Riders (PBR) events, Nitro Circus and Monster Trucks along with the highly successful Kiss concert. ==References== {{Reflist|40em}} {{Rugby League in Queensland}} {{NRL Grounds |state=collapsed}} [[Category:Sports venues in Queensland]] [[Category:Sport in Mackay, Queensland]] [[Category:Mackay Cutters]] [[Category:2011 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2011]] [[Category:Rugby league stadiums in Australia]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Australia]]

{{about|the toy manufactured by Wham-O|other highly resilient balls|bouncy ball|the pricing game|Super Ball (The Price Is Right pricing game)|the championship game|Super Bowl}} [[File:Glitter Super Ball.jpg|thumb|A Super Ball containing particles of glitter, resting on a base. The transparent rubber has yellowed with age.]]
A '''Super Ball''' (a.k.a. '''SuperBall''') is a [[toy]] [[bouncing ball]] based on a type of [[synthetic rubber]] invented in 1964 by chemist [[Norman Stingley]]. It is an extremely [[Elasticity (physics)|elastic]] [[ball]] made of [[Zectron]]<ref name="afads" /> which contains the [[synthetic polymer]] [[polybutadiene]] as well as [[hydrated silica]], [[zinc oxide]], [[stearic acid]], and other ingredients.<ref name="sci&golf"/> This compound is [[vulcanization|vulcanized]] with [[sulfur]] at a temperature of {{val|165|ul=degC}} and formed at a pressure of {{val|3500|ul=psi}}. The resulting Super Ball has a very high [[coefficient of restitution]],<ref name="cross1"/><ref name="MacInnes1"/><ref name="basics of phys"/> and dropped from shoulder level, a Super Ball bounces nearly all the way back; thrown down by an average adult, it can leap over a three-story building.
Toys similar to Super Balls are more generally known as [[bouncy ball]]s, a term that covers other balls by different manufacturers with different formulations.
==History== [[File:Black Super Ball.jpg|thumb|left|A branded Wham-O Super Ball from 2001]] Stingley sought uses for his [[Polybutadiene]] synthetic rubber, as well as someone to manufacture it. He first offered his invention to the Bettis Rubber Company, for whom he worked at the time,<ref>http://www.ideafinder.com/history/inventions/superball.htm</ref> but they turned it down because the material was not very durable.<ref>Wham-O Super Book Celebrating 60 Years Inside the Fun Factory By Tim Walsh {{ISBN|978-0-8118-6445-9}}</ref> So Stingley took it to toy company [[Wham-O]]; they worked on developing a more durable version which they still manufacture today.<ref name="toys-amaz"/><ref name="bg-toy story"/>
"It took us nearly two years to iron the kinks out of Super Ball before we produced it," said [[Richard Knerr]], President of Wham-O in 1966.<ref name="pop sci-invent" /> "It always had that marvelous springiness…. But it had a tendency to fly apart. We've licked that with a very high-pressure technique for forming it. Now we're selling millions." <ref name="pop sci-invent" />
Super Ball became a [[fad]] when it was introduced.<ref name="kallen-ae"/> Peak production reached over 170,000 Super Balls per day.<ref name="rielly-60s"/> By December 1965, over six million had been sold, and U.S. Presidential adviser [[McGeorge Bundy]] had five dozen shipped to the [[White House]] for the amusement of the staff.<ref name="afads"/><ref name="rielly-60s" /><ref name="life-boom"/><ref name="f&mf"/> Wham-O Executive Vice-president Richard P. Knerr knew that fads are short-lived. "Each Super Ball bounce is 92% as high as the last," he once said. "If our sales don't come down any faster than that, we've got it made."<ref name="f&mf" /> Initially, the full-sized Super Ball sold for 98¢ at retail; by the end of 1966, its colorful miniature versions sold for as little as 10¢ in vending machines.<ref name="bb-calif happy"/>
In the late 1960s, Wham-O made a giant Super Ball roughly the size of a bowling ball as a promotional stunt.<ref name="toys-amaz"/><ref name="bg-toy story"/> It fell from the 23rd story window (some reports say the roof) of an Australian hotel and destroyed a parked convertible car on the second bounce.<ref name="toys-amaz"/><ref name="bg-toy story"/>
Composer [[Alcides Lanza]] purchased several Super Balls in 1965 as toys for his son, but soon he started experimenting with the sounds that they made when rubbed along the strings of a piano.<ref name="lanza1" /> This resulted in his composition ''Plectros III'' (1971), in which he specifies that the performer should use a pair of Super Balls on sticks as mallets with which to strike and rub the strings and case of a piano.<ref name="lanza1"/>
[[Lamar Hunt]], founder of the [[American Football League]], watched his children playing with a Super Ball and then coined the term [[Super Bowl]]. He wrote a letter to NFL commissioner [[Pete Rozelle]] dated July 25, 1966: "I have kiddingly called it the 'Super Bowl,' which obviously can be improved upon." The leagues' owners decided on the name "AFL-NFL Championship Game," but the media immediately picked up on Hunt's "Super Bowl" name, which became official beginning with the third annual game.<ref name="toys-amaz" /><ref>MacCambridge, Michael. ''America's Game''. New York: Random House, 2004, p. 237.</ref><ref name="huppke-lotb"/>
==Physical properties== According to one study "If a pen is stuck in a hard rubber ball and dropped from a certain height, the pen may bounce to several times that height."<ref name="harter1"/> If a Super Ball is dropped without spin onto a hard surface, with a small ball bearing on top of the Super Ball, the bearing rebounds to a great height.<ref name="browne"/>
High school physics teachers use Super Balls to educate students on usual and unusual models of impacts.<ref name="nonsmooth"/>
The "rough" nature of a Super Ball makes its impact characteristics different from otherwise similar smooth balls.<ref name="Garwin1"/><ref name="dynsb"/> The resulting behavior is quite complex.<ref name="dynsb"/> The Super Ball has been used as an illustration of the principle of [[T-symmetry|Time Reversal Invariance]].<ref name="Crawford1"/>
A Super Ball is observed to reverse the direction of spin on each bounce.<ref name="bridges1"/><ref name="aston1"/><ref name="cup-im"/> This effect depends on the tangential compliance and frictional effect in the collision. It cannot be explained by rigid body impact theory, and would not occur were the ball perfectly rigid.<ref name="cup-im" /> Tangential compliance is the degree to which one body clings to rather than slips over another at the point of impact.<ref name="cup-im2"/>
==Patent== * [http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?patentnumber=3241834 Stingley, Norman H., — "Highly Resilient Polybutadiene Ball"]

This friction places moments on the ball that cause it to spin after bouncing. Bailey |title=Fashion & Merchandising Fads |publisher=Routledge|date=August 1994|pages=243–244|isbn=1-56024-376-7}}</ref> <ref name="lanza1">{{cite book|last=Jones|first=Pamela |title=Alcides Lanza: Portrait of a Composer |publisher=McGill-Queen's University Press|date=November 2007|pages=131|isbn=0-7735-3264-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GO1U-jH-4Z4C&pg=PA131&dq=Superball&lr=&cd=28#v=onepage&q=Superball&f=false}}</ref> <ref name="huppke-lotb">{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/football/bears/chi-0701300052jan30,1,233400.story?track=rss&ctrack=1&cset=true |title=Legends of the Bowl |accessdate=2007-01-31 |author=Rex W. page.title: The Ring magazine Fighter of the Year

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:''The Ring'' magazine Fighter of the Year}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2016}} ''[[The Ring (magazine)|The Ring]]'' magazine was established in 1922 and has named a '''Fighter of the Year''' since 1928, which this list covers. The award, selected by the magazine editors, is based on a boxer's performance in the ring.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ringtv.craveonline.com/news/182653-past-winners-of-the-ring-year-end-awards|title=Past winners of THE RING year-end awards|date=December 19, 2013|work=[[The Ring (magazine)|The Ring]]|accessdate=June 23, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160116162409/http://ringtv.craveonline.com/news/182653-past-winners-of-the-ring-year-end-awards|archivedate=January 16, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Fighters of the Year by decade==
===1920s===
* 1928{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Gene Tunney]] * 1929{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Tommy Loughran]]
===1930s===
[[File:Barney Ross.jpg|thumb|[[Barney Ross]]]]
* 1930{{snds}}{{Flagicon|GER}} [[Max Schmeling]] * 1931{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Tommy Loughran]] {{small|''(2)''}} * 1932{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Jack Sharkey]] * 1933{{snds}}''no award was given'' * 1934{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Tony Canzoneri]] and {{Flagicon|USA}} [[Barney Ross]] * 1935{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Barney Ross]] {{small|''(2)''}} * 1936{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Joe Louis]] * 1937{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Henry Armstrong]] * 1938{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Joe Louis]] {{small|''(2)''}} * 1939{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Joe Louis]] {{small|''(3)''}}
===1940s===
* 1940{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Billy Conn]] * 1941{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Joe Louis]] {{small|''(4)''}} * 1942{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Sugar Ray Robinson]] * 1943{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Fred Apostoli]] * 1944{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Beau Jack]] * 1945{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Willie Pep]] * 1946{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Tony Zale]] * 1947{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Gus Lesnevich]] * 1948{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Ike Williams (boxer)|Ike Williams]] * 1949{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Ezzard Charles]]
===1950s===
* 1950{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Ezzard Charles]] {{small|''(2)''}} * 1951{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Sugar Ray Robinson]] {{small|''(2)''}} * 1952{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Rocky Marciano]] * 1953{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Bobo Olson]] * 1954{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Rocky Marciano]] {{small|''(2)''}} * 1955{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Rocky Marciano]] {{small|''(3)''}} * 1956{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Floyd Patterson]] * 1957{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Carmen Basilio]] * 1958{{snds}}{{Flagicon|SWE}} [[Ingemar Johansson]] * 1959{{snds}}{{Flagicon|SWE}} [[Ingemar Johansson]] {{small|''(2)''}}
===1960s===
[[File:Ali.jpg|thumb|Muhammad Ali, who was named 'fighter of the year' more times than any other fighter. Was not awarded the honor in 1966 due to draft controversy, but it was retroactively awarded in December 2016. Ali won the award six times in total.]]
* 1960{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Floyd Patterson]] {{small|''(2)''}} * 1961{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Joe Brown (boxer)|Joe Brown]] * 1962{{snds}}{{Flagicon|NGR}} [[Dick Tiger]] * 1963{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Muhammad Ali]] * 1964{{snds}}{{Flagicon|United States Virgin Islands}} [[Emile Griffith]] * 1965{{snds}}{{Flagicon|NGR}} [[Dick Tiger]] {{small|''(2)''}} * 1966{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Muhammad Ali]] {{small|''(2)''}} (retroactively awarded in 2016) * 1967{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Joe Frazier]] * 1968{{snds}}{{Flagicon|ITA}} [[Nino Benvenuti]] * 1969{{snds}}{{Flagicon|CUB}} [[José Nápoles]]
===1970s===

===1980s===

===2000s===

* 2000{{snds}}{{Flagicon|PRI}} [[Félix Trinidad]] * 2001{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Bernard Hopkins]] * 2002{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Vernon Forrest]] * 2003{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[James Toney]] {{small|''(2)''}} * 2004{{snds}}{{Flagicon|JAM}} [[Glen Johnson (boxer)|Glen Johnson]] * 2005{{snds}}{{Flagicon|GRB}} [[Ricky Hatton]] * 2006{{snds}}{{Flagicon|PHI}} [[Manny Pacquiao]] * 2007{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Floyd Mayweather Jr.]] {{small|''(2)''}} * 2008{{snds}}{{Flagicon|PHI}} [[Manny Pacquiao]] {{small|''(2)''}} * 2009{{snds}}{{Flagicon|PHI}} [[Manny Pacquiao]] {{small|''(3)''}}
===2010s===
* 2010{{snds}}{{Flagicon|ARG}} [[Sergio Martínez (boxer)|Sergio Martínez]] * 2011{{snds}}{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Andre Ward]] * 2012{{snds}}{{Flagicon|MEX}} [[Juan Manuel Márquez]] * 2013{{snds}}{{Flagicon|CAN}} [[Adonis Stevenson]] * 2014{{snds}}{{Flagicon|RUS}} [[Sergey Kovalev (boxer)|Sergey Kovalev]] * 2015{{snds}}{{Flagicon|UK}} [[Tyson Fury]] * 2016{{snds}}{{Flagicon|UK}} [[Carl Frampton]] * 2017{{snds}}{{Flagicon|UKR}} [[Vasyl Lomachenko]]

Bishop Fallon High School (Monsignor Martin Athletic Association) (1962–1969) | website = }} {{Location map |USA |relief = 1 |label = Buffalo |lat = 42.905 |long = -78.856 |caption = Location in the [[United States]] |position = bottom |marksize = 5 |float = |background = |width = 240 }} {{Location map |USA New York |relief = 1 |label = Buffalo |lat = 42.905 |long = -78.856 |caption = Location in [[New York (state)|New York]] |position = |marksize = 5 |float = |background = |width = 170 }} '''War Memorial Stadium''' (nicknamed '''The Rockpile''') was an outdoor [[stadium]] in the [[Northeastern United States|northeast]] United States in [[Buffalo, New York]]. It hosted [[Minor League Baseball]] and professional [[American football|football]] teams, most notably the [[Buffalo Bills]] of the [[American Football League]] (AFL), and later [[National Football League]] (NFL). The stadium was on a rectangular block near the downtown area and its baseball diamond had an unorthodox southeast alignment (home plate to center field).{{cite web |url=http://historicaerials.com/?layer=0&zoom=11&lat=42.906&lon=-78.857 |publisher=Historic Aerials |title=42.906 N, 78.857 W |accessdate=January 13, 2016}} The main entrance was in the left field corner at Jefferson Avenue to the east and Best Street to the south (behind right field). Its other boundaries were Dodge Street to the north (behind third base) and Masten Park to the west (behind first base) with Masten Avenue farther west. The east-west alignment of the football field was also unorthodox, running along the third base line. The [[elevation]] at street level is approximately {{convert|650|ft|round=5}} above [[sea level]]. War Memorial Stadium was built as a [[Works Progress Administration|WPA]] project in 1937. It was originally named '''Roesch Memorial Stadium''', though the name was changed to '''[[Grover Cleveland]] Stadium''' later in 1937 (honoring the former President and Buffalo public official) and then to '''Civic Stadium''' in 1938. The name was changed to '''War Memorial Stadium''' in 1960.[http://wnyheritagepress.org/photos_week_2006/civic_stadium/civic_stadium.htm Western New York Heritage Press] The stadium originally sat 35,000, but expansions raised the capacity to over 46,500. Despite this, by the time of the [[AFL–NFL merger]] in [[1970 Buffalo Bills season|1970]], it was one of the league's smallest stadiums (below the league's new 50,000-seat minimum). After considering{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cOVVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5-ADAAAAIBAJ&pg=1870%2C2203803 |newspaper=Eugene Register-Guard |location=(Oregon) |title=Buffalo Bills nearing move to Seattle |date=January 12, 1971 |page=3B}} and rejecting a move to [[Seattle]], the Bills left after the [[1972 Buffalo Bills season|1972]] season for Rich Stadium (now [[New Era Field]]) in suburban [[Orchard Park, New York|Orchard Park]], which had a capacity of over 80,000 in [[1973 Buffalo Bills season|1973]]. ==History== ===Professional tenants=== The stadium hosted the [[Buffalo Bills]] of the [[American Football League]], and later the [[National Football League]] from {{nowrap|[[1960 Buffalo Bills season|1960]] to [[1972 Buffalo Bills season|1972]],}} the unrelated [[Buffalo Bills (AAFC)|Buffalo Bills]] of the [[All-America Football Conference|AAFC]] from {{nowrap|1946 to 1949}} ("Bisons" in 1946), the [[Buffalo Indians]] and [[Buffalo Indians|Chiefs]] of the [[AFL III|third American Football League]] in 1940 and 1941, [[Canisius Golden Griffins|Canisius College]]'s [[Canisius Golden Griffins baseball|baseball]] and [[Canisius Golden Griffins football|football teams]], and baseball's [[Buffalo Bisons]] of the [[International League]] during the 1960s and again from 1979 to 1987 (as part of the [[Eastern League (baseball)|Eastern League]] and [[American Association (20th century)|American Association]]). ===Postseason games hosted=== The stadium hosted three postseason professional football games, all in the [[American Football League]]. *[[1963 American Football League playoffs|1963 AFL Eastern Division playoff]]: [[1963 Boston Patriots season|Boston Patriots]] 26, [[1963 Buffalo Bills season|Buffalo Bills]] 8 on December 28, 1963 *[[1964 American Football League Championship Game|1964 AFL Championship Game]]: [[1964 Buffalo Bills season|Buffalo Bills]] 20, [[1964 San Diego Chargers season|San Diego Chargers]] 7 on December 26, 1964 *[[1966 American Football League Championship Game|1966 AFL Championship Game]]: [[1966 Kansas City Chiefs season|Kansas City Chiefs]] 31, [[1966 Buffalo Bills season|Buffalo Bills]] 7 on January 1, 1967 ===Final years=== In its later years, War Memorial Stadium was poorly maintained. [[Ron Fimrite]], writing in ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' in 1984, quoted another writer, [[Brock Yates]], as having once said this stadium "looks as if whatever war it was a memorial to had been fought within its confines."{{cite news |url=https://www.si.com/vault/1984/05/07/626594/a-star-with-real-clout# |magazine=Sports Illustrated |last=Fimrite |authorlink=Ron Fimrite |first=Ron |title=A Star with Real Clout |date=May 7, 1984 |page=100}} That look contributed to the oft-used nickname Buffalo residents gave it: ''The Rockpile''. Ironically, that worn-down look worked perfectly for the [[1984 in film|1984]] film ''[[The Natural (film)|The Natural]]'', about which Fimrite was writing. All of the baseball scenes in that movie were filmed here in 1983,{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JXhGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xSwNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1435%2C1816180 |newspaper=Evening News |location=Newburgh, New York |agency=Associated Press |title=Redford movie being filmed in Buffalo |date=June 16, 1983 |page=8B }}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2LdaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=glkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4535%2C992417 |newspaper=St. Petersburg Independent |location=Florida |last=Mulcahy |first=Susan |title=Buffalo wins out for Redford flick |date=July 20, 1983 |page=18B }} except for the one scene set at [[Chicago]]'s [[Wrigley Field]], which was filmed at Buffalo's [[All-High Stadium]]. The movie was set in the late 1930s, when the stadium was new. The stadium was deemed unsuitable for [[National Football League]] play after the [[AFL–NFL merger]]. As part of a deal with Congress clearing the way for the merger, the NFL declared stadiums seating fewer than 50,000 people were not suitable for league needs. War Memorial Stadium only seated 46,500 people at its height, and could not be expanded. This led to the Bills constructing what was then called Rich Stadium (now called [[New Era Field]]) in suburban [[Orchard Park, New York|Orchard Park]] and vacating War Memorial Stadium after the [[1972 Buffalo Bills season|1972]] season. After the Bills' departure, the stadium sat dormant from 1973 to 1978. The last tenant of War Memorial Stadium was the [[Buffalo Bisons]], a franchise revived in 1979 before moving to a new downtown stadium, known as [[Sahlen Field|Pilot Field]], in [[1988 in sports|1988]]. The last major event at War Memorial Stadium was a Bisons game against the [[Nashville Sounds]] (the Sounds won, 7–5) on August 30, 1987; the game drew a capacity crowd of nearly 40,000 spectators.Harrington, Mike (August 30, 2012). [http://blogs.buffalonews.com/insidepitch/2012/08/bisons-rockpile-finale.html Bisons' Rockpile finale was 25 years ago today]. ''The Buffalo News''. Retrieved August 30, 2012. Following after the game was a slowpitch softball match between members of the Buffalo media. Doug Smith, a freelance newspaper columnist and [[WIVB-TV]] personality, led the winning team.[http://buffalonews.com/2017/04/20/doug-smith-81-colorful-newsman-sportswriter-tv-personality/ Doug Smith, 81, colorful newsman, sportswriter and TV personality] ==Johnnie B. Wiley Amateur Athletic Sports Pavilion== [[Image:War Memorial Stadium Rockpile field.JPG|thumb|210px|Baseball diamond and football field]] War Memorial Stadium was demolished shortly after the Bisons moved downtown to [[Sahlen Field|Pilot Field]]. A high school athletic field (Johnnie B. Wiley Amateur Athletic Sports Pavilion – c. 1997) remains at the old site and serves as one of Buffalo's three major high school football fields (the others being [[All-High Stadium]] and the field at [[Riverside Institute of Technology]]); the field also was the home of the Buffalo Gladiators, an adult amateur football team. The northwest and southwest entrance to the old stadium was demolished, but the northeast and southeast entrance was saved and preserved. A small baseball diamond is on the former field's southwest corner. ==See also== *[[Buffalo Memorial Auditorium]] *[[All-High Stadium]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} 2. The site is currently used for grammar school track & field events. ==External links== *[http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2005/Buffalo_old/Buffalo_old.htm War Memorial Stadium (2005 Site) Views - ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] *[http://www.frontiernet.net/~rochballparks/buffalo/wm.htm Photographs of War Memorial Stadium - ''Rochester Area Ballparks''] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZDMcPnNOZb4&NR=1 A photo slide show of War Memorial Stadium] *[http://rockpile.buffalonet.org/ A Visual Tour of the Ol' Rockpile] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Buffalo Bills]] | years = 1960 – 1972 | before = first stadium | after = [[Rich Stadium]] }} {{succession box | title = Home of the
[[Buffalo Bisons]] | years = 1960–1970
1979–1987 | before = [[Offermann Stadium]] | after = [[Sahlen Field|Pilot Field]] }} {{end}} {{AFL III}} {{Defunct NFL stadiums}} {{Buffalo(NY)}} {{Buffalo Bills}} {{Buffalo Bisons}} {{Canisius Golden Griffins football navbox}} [[Category:American Football League venues]] [[Category:Buffalo Bills stadiums]] [[Category:Canisius Golden Griffins baseball]] [[Category:Canisius Golden Griffins football]] [[Category:Sports venues in Buffalo, New York]] [[Category:Defunct National Football League venues]] [[Category:Defunct baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:American football venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Baseball venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Defunct minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Defunct college football venues]] [[Category:American Football League (1940) venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1937]] [[Category:1937 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:High school football venues in the United States]]

revision.text:
The '''World Drug-Free Powerlifting Federation''' ('''WDFPF''') is an international powerlifting federation with 22 member countries. Specifically as a drug-free alternative international platform – in order to provide fair competition world-wide for those powerlifters who wish to train and compete without performance-enhancing drugs. This remains as important today as it was when the Federation came into being. In pursuit of this objective the '''WDFPF''' has adopted the most rigorous drug control procedures in the world. That same rigor is demanded of all those national organizations affiliated to the '''WDFPF''', as a pre-condition of their registration with the world body. It is the only international organization which makes such demands of its members, and this is the true measure of their dedication to the drug-free principle. The '''WDFPF''' was founded in 1988, its current president is Wim Backelant.
"The '''WDFPF''' offers both '''equipped''' and '''unequipped''' lifting. In the equipped division single ply bench shirts are allowed in polyester or denim. Canvas and open backed shirts are not allowed. Single ply lifting suits are allowed in polyester. Canvas and denim are not allowed. Briefs are not legal. Knee wraps are fine up to 2m".
'''[[Powerlifting]]''' '''-''' is a strength sport that consists of three attempts at maximal weight on three lifts: [[Squat (exercise)|squat]], [[bench press]], and [[deadlift]].
'''Equipped Competing -''' equipped lifters compete separately from raw lifters. Equipped lifters will wear a squat suit, knee wraps, a bench shirt, and a deadlift suit. These four things are the things that separate equipped lifters and raw lifters.
'''Unequipped Competing or "RAW"-''' maintains strict guidelines regarding tools and accessories competitors may use during competition. The only equipment that is allowed in raw meets are wrist wraps, knee sleeves, and a weightlifting belt. {| class="wikitable" !Contents |- | # World Championship |- |2. List of National Affiliates by Region |- | |} '''(WDFPF)World Championship/World record holders within the federation'''

{{Infobox recurring event | name = World Police and Fire Games | native_name = | native_name_lang = | logo = Sponsor-7.jpg | logo_caption = logo | image = | caption = | status = active | genre = sports event | date = | begins = | ends = | frequency = biennial | venue = | location = various | coordinates = | country = | years_active = | first = {{Start date|1985|df=y}} | founder_name = | last = | prev = | next = | participants = | attendance = | area = | budget = | activity = | patron = | organised = | filing = | people = | member = | sponsor = | website = | footnotes = }} [[File:Police and Fire Hockey (19275390946).jpg|thumb|[[Ice Hockey]] at the 2015 games in Fairfax, Virginia]] The '''World Police and Fire Games''' (WPFG) is a biennial athletic event, open to active and retired law enforcement and fire service personnel throughout the world. The WPFG Federation is an arm of the California Police Athletic Federation (CPAF),<ref>{{cite web|title=World Police & Fire Games At A Glance|url=http://www.cpaf.org/wpfg|publisher=CPAF|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> an American non-profit organization.
The Games attract approximately 10,000 entrants, slightly fewer than the Summer [[Olympic Games]], and exceeding the third position holder, the [[Commonwealth Games]]. In the early 2010s, [[The United Kingdom]] hosted all three events consecutively; the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in [[London]], [[England]], followed by the 2013 World Police and Fire Games in [[Belfast]], [[Northern Ireland]], and ending with [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]], hosting the 2014 [[Commonwealth Games]] - the first time all three events have been hosted by the same nation consecutively.
The host city of the 2015 World Police and Fire Game was [[Fairfax County, Virginia]], in the United States, with venues located around the [[Washington metropolitan area]].<ref>{{cite web|title=World Police & Fire Games, Fairfax 2015|url=http://fairfax2015.com/}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Pier 95 Irene France WPFG jeh.jpg|thumb|French team in New York on a day [[Hurricane Irene|a hurricane]] cancelled competition in 2011]] The California Police Olympics were first held in 1967. The concept evolved over the years and led to the creation of the World Police & Fire Games Federation—a non-profit organization, run by the Californian Police Athletics Federation—in 1983. Two years later, in 1985, the first World Police & Fire Games were held in [[San Jose, California]], USA, with nearly 5,000 competitors.<ref>[http://2011wpfg.org/WPFGHistory/tabid/56/Default.aspx History of the World Police & Fire Games]. 2011 World Police & Fire Games. Retrieved 2011-09-04.</ref>
The largest WPFG games to date was held in New York, New York, USA with over 16,000 athletes in attendance, from 59 nations.<ref name=2015Fairfax/>
The most successful and best organised was in [[Belfast]], [[Northern Ireland]] in 2013.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-23589848 BBC News - In pictures: World Police and Fire Games 2013]. Bbc.co.uk (2013-08-08). Retrieved on 2014-04-12.</ref> It was described, by the President of the World Police and Fire Games Federation, Mike Graham, as "the friendliest and best Games ever".<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-23649271 BBC News - WPFG 'best and friendliest ever', says president of games]. Bbc.co.uk (2013-08-10). Retrieved on 2014-04-12.</ref>
The Montreal Firefighters Association has called for a boycott of the 2017 Games, which are to be held in their own city, in protest against forced changes to their collective agreements and pension funds by the City of Montreal and the Quebec provincial government. Labor unions representing over 100,000 firefighters and civil servants have joined Montreal's firefighters in this boycott.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/firefighters-boycotting-2017-world-firefighters-games-in-montreal-1.3149582 | title=Firefighters boycotting 2017 World Firefighters Games in Montreal | publisher=CBC News | work=Kate McKenna | date=15 July 2015 | accessdate=17 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://wpfg2017.com/ | title=Montreal World Police and Fire Games Boycott | publisher=Montreal World Police and Fire Games | accessdate=17 January 2016}}</ref>
